text:
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts about where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you are also telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet. This made people more aware that sharing everything online might have negative sides. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a global audience, offering dreams of wealth and fame. So, we dive into the internet, sharing personal stories and photos. But soon, we realize it can be risky and confusing.

This might sound sad, but don't lose hope. There is a guide for this future, created by early internet users. In the early days of the web, these pioneers explored and faced many challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with fame, all before social media existed. These first bloggers have already experienced what many of us are going through now. Before we forget their stories, we should learn from them. As the saying goes, those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was invented at Cern, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were interested in his bold use of this new medium. Hall's rule was simple: if you crossed his path, you might appear on his site, and no topic was off-limits. His work was very open, but it also had a certain beauty that some might call art.

One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video called Dark Night. He shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped the blog, but the problem remains. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you, you might be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online they wouldn't say in person. But the web is not a separate world where we can say anything without consequences. Our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to big mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. Though she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and started blogging again about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned that while the web lets us say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

Text: 'Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we do not understand. Scientists usually agree with this idea because no one knows everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt they needed to warn the public about the film. They used strong words like ‘atrocious’ and ‘dangerous’ to describe it. This made the film seem interesting to watch. At first, the film seemed harmless. Scientists in the film said that new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being changed by thoughts. I had heard before that a Japanese researcher showed that thoughts could change the shape of water molecules. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy and looking bad after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. Some people find this evidence convincing because it is simple and clear. But scientists usually say, ‘Give me a break’. They mean that we need real proof that thoughts can change water. Nice pictures of crystals are not enough. The real issue is that the film’s claims were not strange enough. For example, water molecules might have properties from a form of energy that comes from nowhere and is linked to a force expanding the universe. This idea is supported by years of research in labs and observatories. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is pushed by a mysterious force called ‘dark energy’. Besides the film, other discoveries are also amazing. Neuroscientists found that our brain takes about half a second to process events, but we do not notice this delay. Anthropologists think they know where modern humans first lived and why they moved to other places. Some theorists say there are links between life on Earth and the universe’s design. Science is not finished. We are further from knowing everything than ever before. Chaos and quantum uncertainty show limits to what we can know. Some physicists are trying to create a Theory of Everything to explain all forces and particles in one equation. Many people think the universe is best described in one word: incredible.'

Text: 'In simple terms, I find writing novels challenging and writing short stories enjoyable. Writing novels is like planting a forest, while writing short stories is like planting a garden. Both activities complement each other, creating a complete landscape that I value. The trees provide shade, and the wind moves the leaves, which sometimes turn gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing the change of seasons. Since I started my career as a fiction writer, I have alternated between writing novels and short stories. My pattern is this: after finishing a novel, I want to write short stories; after completing short stories, I focus on a novel. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and vice versa. The two types of writing might use different parts of the brain, and it takes time to switch between them. I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. I knew little about it then, so it was difficult, but the experience was memorable. I felt my fictional world expand. Readers seemed to like this other side of me as a writer. One of my first works, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. This was my start as a short-story writer. One joy of writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to shape a short story (though revisions can be endless). It’s not like the long commitment needed for a novel, which can take a year or two. You go into a room, finish your work, and leave. That’s it. Writing a novel can feel like it goes on forever, and I sometimes wonder if I’ll make it. So, writing short stories is a necessary change of pace. Another nice thing about short stories is that you can create them from small things – an idea, a word, an image. It’s like jazz improvisation, with the story leading me. Also, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If the idea doesn’t work, you just move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t make every short story a masterpiece. This comforts me. You can learn from your mistakes and use that in the next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from the successes and failures of my short stories. In this way, short stories are like an experimental lab for me as a novelist. It’s hard to experiment in a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be more difficult. My short stories are like soft shadows I have set out in the world, faint footprints I have left behind. I remember where I wrote each one and how I felt. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy to share these feelings with my readers.'

Science can be very abstract, like philosophy, or very practical, like curing diseases. It has made our lives easier but also brought dangers. Science tries to understand everything from tiny ants to the vast universe, but it doesn't always succeed. It influences poets, politicians, and thinkers. Its beauty is often seen only by experts, and its dangers are often misunderstood. People sometimes think science is more or less important than it really is, and they often ignore its mistakes or exaggerate them. Science is full of conflicts. Old ideas are often changed or replaced by new ones, just like in music. New ideas are sometimes laughed at but can become the new standard. Scientists can be jealous and angry. The history of science is about conflict. This book will talk about ideas in science that changed not just science but also human thought. We will focus on ideas, not practical things like non-stick pans. We will admire these ideas but also question them, knowing that human minds have limits. Science is always changing. Scientists often prove each other wrong. Usually, these changes don't affect society much, but sometimes they change our beliefs. In the 17th century, science showed us a universe like a big clock. Three centuries later, physics made us question basic ideas, showing us that observing the universe can change it. Some people think science can't explain everything, but it often helps us understand and predict nature better. Isaac Newton explained more than Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained more than Newton. Science makes mistakes but keeps going. At the end of the 19th century, many thought there was nothing new to discover in physics, but then came many new discoveries like radioactivity and quantum mechanics. Biology has also made many discoveries. Some people now say we are close to a complete theory of everything. Maybe. Science is not just a harmless hobby. In the last 200 years, we have started to control nature more, sometimes upsetting its balance. We need to watch science carefully. People who are not scientists need to understand scientific advances because they affect the world and future generations. Science is now part of how we plan and control our future. This is not just a question for philosophers. The answers can affect national budgets, the health of future children, and even life on Earth.

Text: 'Around 2015, after years of growth, big publishers noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people question the future of ebooks in publishing. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, as his company lost faith in 'the power of the word on the page'. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will 'kill' print books. Whether predicting or dismissing this, the idea of books disappearing makes us think and debate. Why is this idea so strong? Why do we see ebooks and print books as fighting, even if the facts say otherwise? The answers are not just about ebooks; they show how we feel about new things and change. In my research, I found that people often think one new technology will replace another. Before digital tech, people thought new inventions would end old media. For example, when TV was invented, many thought radio would die, but radio survived by finding new uses, like in cars. The idea of books disappearing isn't new. In 1894, people thought the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times. Movies, radio, TV, and smartphones have all been seen as threats to print books. Some said losing books would harm culture, while others thought ebooks were much better. The idea of books dying comes up during times of tech change. This story shows our hopes and fears about new technology. We form emotional connections with media as they become part of our lives. Studies show we bond with things like books and computers, even naming our cars or getting mad at our laptops. So, when new tech like e-readers comes, it changes our bond with things we use every day. As tech changes, we miss what we used to have. This is why industries grow around old products and tech. When the printing press spread in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. The move from silent to sound movies in the 1920s made people miss silent films. The same happened with analog to digital photography and vinyl records to CDs. E-readers made people appreciate 'old' books and even their smell. This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of a disappearing medium will keep being a popular story about tech change and our dislike of change. We use stories of tragedy and ending to understand change. The story of the death of the book shows our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our world and ourselves.'

Text: 'Almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made a cup of coffee, and sat down to write about how some of the greatest minds of the past 400 years managed their daily work. I wanted to see how they found time each day to be creative and productive. By writing about the simple details of their daily lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I hoped to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show them as people with habits, just like us. The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, ‘Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.’ I say, ‘Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward.’ In this way, my book is about the conditions of creative work, not the work itself. It’s about how things are made, not what they mean. But it’s also personal. The novelist John Cheever thought that even writing a business letter shows something about your inner self. My book looks at questions I struggle with: How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to focus completely on one project or to work on it a little each day? When there isn’t enough time for everything, do you have to give things up, or can you learn to do more in less time? I don’t have all the answers, but I have tried to show how different successful people have faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas come from small daily actions; how your work habits affect your work, and vice versa. The book’s title is Daily Rituals, but it’s really about people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary, but it can also be a way to use your time, willpower, and optimism wisely. A good routine helps you focus your mental energy and avoid being controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot; by forming good habits, he said, we can ‘free our minds to advance to really interesting fields of action.’ Ironically, James himself often procrastinated and couldn’t keep a regular schedule. This book started from my own procrastination. One Sunday afternoon, I was alone at the small architecture magazine where I worked, trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was tidying my desk and making coffee. I’m a ‘morning person’ who can focus well in the early hours but not after lunch. That afternoon, to feel better about this, I started looking online for information about other writers’ work schedules. I found many interesting stories. I thought someone should collect these stories in one place – so I started the Daily Routines blog that afternoon, and now, this book. The blog was simple; I posted descriptions of people’s routines as I found them in biographies, magazine profiles, and newspaper obituaries. For the book, I’ve collected a much larger and better-researched set of routines, while keeping the short and varied voices that made the blog popular. I’ve let my subjects speak for themselves as much as possible, using quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I’ve summarized their routines from other sources. I should mention that this book wouldn’t be possible without the work of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also guide further reading.'

Howard became a palaeontologist because of a change in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, had a big loan and was worried about how the economy would affect him. He said that the planned holiday to Spain was no longer possible. Instead, they rented a small house on the English coast. On a rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. He knew for a long time that he wanted to be a palaeontologist, and by the end of university, he knew what kind he wanted to be. He was interested in the very early times, not in dinosaurs. He studied small creatures in grey rocks. When he finished his doctoral thesis, he wondered if he would get a job, especially in the kind of place he wanted. He believed in himself but knew that deserving something doesn't always mean you get it. When a job at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied, but he wasn't very hopeful. On the day of Howard’s interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had an argument with his wife, crashed his car, and went to the hospital. The interview happened without him, and the professor who replaced him wanted to stop the appointment of his rival’s favorite candidate. This helped Howard get the job. Howard was surprised by the support from someone he didn’t know and was grateful until a colleague explained what really happened. Howard was a little disappointed but happy to have the job he wanted. He often thought about how his work life was organized, but personal life could be chaotic. He realized that strangers could change your life, like when his briefcase with lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. Angry, Howard went back to the college, postponed the lecture, and reported the theft. He then had coffee with a colleague and a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. This is how Howard learned about a new collection of fossils that would be his biggest challenge and secure his career. If not for the theft, he wouldn’t have known. He quickly changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Charles Spence will eat almost anything. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. These larvae might look like maggots, but they have a "slightly nutty, floral" taste. Making bug-eating normal is just one of the challenges Spence and his team are working on. Spence studies how our senses work together to create the flavors we taste. His research is quietly changing what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurants. Spence and his colleagues study how we experience food and drink, a field informally called gastrophysics. They look at who we eat with, how food is presented, the color and texture of plates and cutlery, and background noise—all of which affect taste. Spence’s book, "The Perfect Meal," written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, is full of interesting facts for anyone who likes food. Did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant enjoys their food the most? Or that we eat about 35% more when dining with one other person, and 75% more with three others? Spence’s lab in Oxford is simple and low-tech. There are soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work creatively with chefs who can't afford research. Much of his work is funded by a big food company. In the past, research funded by industry was seen as less serious in universities. But now, since the government wants universities to show their work has an impact, this research is seen as valuable. Spence is helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar, often because of government rules. They do it slowly so customers don’t notice the change. "Research shows that if you tell people about the changes, they focus on the taste and don’t like it as much," he says. Spence met Heston Blumenthal, a famous experimental chef, while working on a project. People used to think science and food didn’t mix, but most food is scientific. Blumenthal and Spence created the "Sound of the Sea" dish, which uses sound to enhance flavor. Spence says that the Italian futurists were doing similar things a century ago, but it didn’t become popular. Now, the food industry uses Spence’s sensory science widely. For example, higher-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and lower-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon match music with food for passengers. Last year, a brand released an app that played music while ice cream softened, but they didn’t match the music to the taste, which Spence says happens often. What are dinner parties like at Spence’s home? Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled lights. They’ve had parties with a tone generator, headphones, and different drinks to see if they have different pitches. For Spence, home, shops, food events, and conferences are all part of his lab.

Our brains are busier than ever. We get a lot of information, some true and some not, and we have to decide what is important. We also do more things ourselves now. For example, we book our own flights and find things in shops without help. We try to manage our lives, families, jobs, hobbies, and TV shows, often using our smartphones. But there is a problem. We think we are multitasking, doing many things at once, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a scientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. We actually switch quickly from one task to another, which makes us less efficient. Multitasking increases stress hormones, which can make us feel confused. It also makes our brains want more new things, which distracts us. The part of the brain that helps us focus is easily distracted by new things. Just having the chance to multitask can hurt our thinking. Glenn Wilson, a psychologist, found that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. This is worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain that stores skills, not facts. Without TV, it goes to a part that organizes information better. Multitasking also involves making decisions, which is hard for our brains. Even small decisions use a lot of brain power, and after many small decisions, we might make bad big decisions. Many people, including business leaders and scientists, say email is a big problem. It's not email itself, but the large amount of communication. One scientist's son said his dad's job is "answering emails," which is almost true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it seems impossible to do that and other tasks.

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right position to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions would not have been important. Scientists studied animal behaviors and their results, but they did not think animals had feelings or moral systems. Recently, this has started to change. Research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens is beginning to explore animal emotions. This change has led to popular science books like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This has started a debate: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? In a recent experiment, cows had to open a locked gate to get food. Cows that opened the gate themselves showed more happiness by jumping and kicking than those that had the gate opened for them. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? The observations are clear, but their meaning is debated. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, author of "Second Nature," believes we should stop eating meat. He thinks we are near a big change in ethics, like when slavery ended. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, says we should rethink how we see animal intelligence. He believes animals have a simpler version of a "theory of mind" than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop giving animals human traits. The disagreement is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since defining consciousness is hard, can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment that suggests starlings, a type of bird, can feel depressed. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group lived in nice cages with space and water, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid unpleasant worms from another. Later, when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt pessimistic. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, has a strong opinion. He says, "We look back with horror at times of racism. One day, we will feel the same about how we treat animals. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger." If Balcombe were alone in his views, it might be easy to dismiss him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning, who wrote a textbook on animal behavior, says, "We are seeing a change. In the early 20th century, some thought animals were like us, and there was a reaction against that. Now we are changing again. It is a difficult topic, and we should avoid personal opinions."

Text: 'Critical thinking is a way of understanding what we read or listen to. Adrian West, from the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., says that argument can help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems and make it harder to think deeply. West says we see a lot of poor thinking and opinions that can confuse us. More data does not always mean better knowledge or decisions. The National Endowment for the Arts says reading has dropped by 10%, and this might affect critical thinking. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, believes focusing on visual media can reduce critical thinking. She says people now prefer real-time media and multi-tasking over focusing on one thing. We don't yet know exactly how technology affects critical thinking. Technology can be both good and bad. For example, a computer game might help or hurt critical thinking. Reading online can improve analysis, but too many links can stop deep thinking. Greenfield says technology changes how we think. Reading helps imagination and critical thinking more than video games and TV, but visual media can improve some information processing. Most visual media do not allow time for reflection or imagination. This can lead to people, especially young ones, not reaching their full potential. How we see technology affects our views on critical thinking. Video games and thinking skills are a big topic. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, says video games can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills. They let players explore ideas in virtual worlds. As reading and math scores go down, we need to understand how technology affects thinking and analysis.'

Matthew Crawford is a writer and motorcycle mechanic. He left his office job because he was unhappy with it. His first book talks about the benefits of manual work. His latest book is about dealing with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. Crawford noticed that these ads are hard to ignore and take our attention away from what we want to think about. This makes it difficult to remember conversations or think deeply. Because of this, people avoid talking to strangers and prefer to be alone.

Crawford says we often see the world through things like video games and phone apps, which can control our desires. Many people are worried about this. For example, some office workers complain about emails but spend their free time checking them. Studies show that just seeing a phone on a table can distract us. There is no proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing.

Crawford believes technology has made it easy for us to focus on ourselves. We often choose to send text messages instead of talking to people. This can make us lose important social connections. He gives an example of his gym, where people used to share music. Now, everyone listens to their own music with earphones, which makes the gym less social.

Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need rules to reduce noise and distractions in public places. More importantly, he thinks we should engage in skilled activities, like cooking or playing sports, to connect with the real world. These activities require good judgment and interaction with others. They help us focus on real experiences instead of digital ones. This doesn't mean everyone should become a chef, but it's important to use our judgment. Focusing on one thing can help us pay attention to what really matters.

Text: "‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often define ourselves by our jobs. Usually, we answer this question in a few words. But when you are a philosopher, like me, it is a bit harder. Saying you are a philosopher can sound pretentious. People might think you claim to know some special truth. This is not true; philosophers are just like everyone else. But this idea makes me pause. Why do people think this way about philosophers? One reason is that philosophers are seen as people who judge others and value intellectual life. The Greek philosopher Aristotle (384 – 322 BCE) said that a life of thinking, or a philosophical life, was the best. Few modern philosophers agree, but philosophy is still linked with thinking deeply. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said, ‘the unexamined life is not worth living’. He meant that just accepting what everyone else does is not satisfying. Thinking about life helps us make our own decisions. But you don’t need to read a lot of philosophy books to think about life. It means looking closely at our daily experiences to see if they are important. It doesn’t mean living away from society. In fact, thinking about life should be practical and shared with others. This is part of a good life. Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become distant from everyday life. This is not all the philosophers' fault. Universities focus on expensive and hard-to-access journals. So, philosophers often only talk to other experts. For most people, philosophy seems far from reality. If philosophers once tried to change this view, many have stopped. Universities created this isolated environment, and academics have supported it. Some areas of philosophy are now very technical, making it hard to explain to non-experts. Philosophy, in some cases, has moved away from society. This needs to change. I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I work in ethics, which is about judging human actions. But I feel this title is not enough because ethics is often linked to rules and laws. Recently, ethics has come to mean applied ethics, which looks at the fairness of social practices. Ethicists today decide if something is ‘ethical’ or acceptable. These are important questions, and I often think about them. But philosophy is more than this. A discussion might start with whether downloading films illegally is wrong (it is) and then look at responsibility, art, and consumerism. Philosophy helps us examine the actions and beliefs that shape our lives. Sometimes we find what we already know; other times, we see our beliefs are hard to defend. By examining these ideas, we help everyone."

Text: 'People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and gourmands, might think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. Historically, though, philosophers have not focused much on food itself. Instead, they often used eating as a way to talk about other ideas, like learning. Sometimes, discussions that seem to be about food are actually about other, loosely related topics. 

An interesting example is the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus. He talked about seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many parts of life. However, his name is now often linked with a love for eating and drinking. We see his name used in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites. These businesses likely hope that being associated with a famous philosopher will help them sell more.

Food is social and cultural. It comes from history and is shared with others in our communities. These communities give us people to eat with and the systems to grow and share food. We interact with food more often and in more basic ways than with any other product, making it an important topic to think about.

Once food is made, critics talk and write about it. But why do they have such a special role? One philosopher says that tasting food is not a special skill, but that food critics are just better at describing tastes. This area has not been studied much because most research on perception focuses on sight, not taste.

Another part of food is its beauty. We often say paintings or music are beautiful, but not food. Some philosophers think that with modern cooking, food should be part of discussions about beauty, like art or poetry. But food is eaten and disappears, unlike art or music, which last over time. So, some say food cannot be considered in the same way.

There are many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our choices often show our beliefs. Philosophers ask why we make these choices, and discussing this is important.

Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a special duty to their guests because of personal relationships. At home, everyone shares food and friendship. Professional cooks have responsibilities to their employers and the food. Their kitchens are for qualified people, and their relationships are professional.

A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ looks at how food can help bridge cultural gaps. This happens in two ways. First, we can appreciate other cultures by enjoying their food. Second, eating together helps us connect with people from different cultures, a practice used in international diplomacy. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories, making this part of food philosophy engaging for readers.'

Rob Daviau, from the US, creates 'legacy' board games. He felt that the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. So, he thought about how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices in one game affect the next one? He changed a classic game called Risk to make a new version: Risk Legacy. In this game, choices made during play have a lasting effect. Players might have to tear up cards, write on the board, or open packets with new rules. The game is played over a set number of sessions, and past actions become part of the game. Daviau said: ‘You could point to the board and say: “Right here! You did this!”’

Daviau then worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players try to stop diseases. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very popular, SeaFall was a big test for the legacy style because it was not based on an earlier game. Set in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century), players explore and conquer new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all possible player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how the game will play out. Jaime Barriga, a tester for SeaFall, said: ‘It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the first few games are great, but then it starts to have problems, and you have to fix everything.’

Legacy games were not expected to become very popular. Even Daviau thought it would be a small interest. ‘When I was working on it, I thought: “This is different and good,”’ he said. ‘But it’s strange and breaks many rules. I thought only a few people would like it.’ However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He thinks it’s a big step forward in game design. ‘It’s a new level of commitment, excitement,’ he said. ‘There’s nothing more exciting for a board gamer than learning a new game or way to play.’

Another fan, Ben Hogg, liked the adventure of legacy games more than worrying about the game lasting. ‘At first, I was worried about changing and ruining the board,’ he said. ‘But Pandemic Legacy changed that. Most people don’t watch the same movie twice, do they? You’re buying an experience. It’s like the stories in video games.’ The legacy style is influenced by video games and popular TV series. Daviau wanted to be a TV writer in college but moved to advertising and then game design. He still loved telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compares making a legacy game to writing a novel. ‘You need to know how it starts and ends,’ he said. ‘But you also need more than just an outline.’

While Daviau feels proud of his work, he is interested in seeing what others do with the idea. But he also thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, from the publisher of SeaFall, believes the legacy style is a big change. ‘It changes how you think about what a board game can be,’ he said.

Text: 'One night not long ago, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and squeezed into a drain leading to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online and seemed like something from a children's movie. Stories like this, about animals escaping, are fun because we like to think animals are like us. This is especially true for octopuses, which are very smart but look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and even play in complex ways. 

Some people think it's unscientific to say animals are like humans, but Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies primates like gorillas and chimpanzees, disagrees. He says that not recognizing human-like traits in animals, which he calls anthropodenial, is more common. He has studied animal behavior for many years and found that animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. Animals are smarter than we often think.

In the past, people thought animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even in the nineteenth century, scientists like Charles Darwin believed that the difference between human and animal minds was one of degree, not kind. But in the twentieth century, people started to see animals as machines that respond to stimuli or as robots with instincts. This view came at a time when humans were destroying animal habitats and not caring for animal welfare.

Dr. de Waal believes we are now starting to see animal intelligence as similar to human intelligence, though not the same. He says that the best tests of animal intelligence consider the unique skills of each species. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hid nuts. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not smart because we can't change our skin color.

Dr. de Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean, but he knows that stories like Inky's help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers got upset. This study was published in a scientific journal, but a video of the experiment convinced more people. This shows how our minds work in interesting ways.'

Text: 'Robotics, once only in science fiction, is now a major technological change. Robots have been used in car and manufacturing industries for many years. Experts say robots will soon be used in many more areas, but many countries are not ready for this big change. Most people know robots will change jobs. About two-thirds of people think robots will do most jobs in 50 years, but 80% think their own jobs will still exist. This is not true: all job areas will be affected by robots soon. For example, an Australian company, Fastbrick Robotics, made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, a job that takes two people almost a day. In San Francisco, a company called Simbe Robotics made Tally, a robot that checks if supermarket shelves are stocked and priced correctly. People who support robots say they will create new jobs for technicians and programmers. Critics say we need to remember the importance of human skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change jobs. His team says that in two years, one-third of robots will be smarter and work with humans. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will make laws about robots. In five years, salaries in robotics will go up by 60%, but many jobs will be empty because there are not enough skilled workers. Zhang says lower-skilled workers will be affected and need to retrain. New robots will also be made for homes and will interact with us in new ways. This is a big chance for companies, but also a challenge because we need new rules for safety and privacy. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future. Countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) to stay competitive.'

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it's there." The reporter was asking a question many people have: why would someone do something so dangerous? Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams. It suggests that climbing is about adventure and fun. 

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called ‘Games that Climbers Play’. He described seven different types of climbing, each with its own rules. He said that the way you climb should depend on the rules of the type of climbing you are doing. Over the years, this idea has become very popular in the climbing community.

Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. However, climbing can also be limiting, like when a storm traps you in a tent. This shows a paradox: climbing can feel both freeing and restricting. But some say that having fewer choices makes life simpler, which is a kind of freedom.

US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He thinks climbing is in our genes. We naturally want to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it's risky. So, the joy of climbing might be more about biology than logic.

US academic Brian Treanor wrote that climbing can help develop important virtues like courage, humility, and respect for nature. He believes these virtues are important in today's world, which often avoids risk. Climbing can help people develop traits that are useful in everyday life.

Some climbers believe that climbing without help from others or technology requires total commitment. Experts Ebert and Robinson argued that climbing is more impressive when done independently, without things like bottled oxygen. This idea caused some controversy because it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

Climbing can also be understood by looking beyond Western ideas. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "in the zone" while climbing. The physical effort, meditation, and problem-solving involved in climbing are similar to techniques in Zen philosophy, which aims for a state of perfect peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

Text: 'For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became very important in classical music. He was a serious and thoughtful person who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot, but he did not teach much. People who knew him well saw that he could be fun, but he did not show this side in his concerts. His life was full of study, travel, and performances. 

Then, four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take him seriously. He had not taught many students and did not plan to start. He said, ‘You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play. He said, ‘Kit played very well and from memory. He gave me a CD of a small concert he did, and he played so beautifully that I thought, “I have to make time for him.” It was a performance that took you from the first to the last note. It’s rare to find a musician with this kind of understanding and skill.’

As Brendel is leaving the public stage, Kit is starting to enter it, but Brendel is careful that Kit does not get too tired too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy when not in lessons. He learns new languages, studies math, writes computer code, or plays tennis, all with his mother watching over him. He also composes music. Brendel says, ‘This is very important. Learning to read music well is easier if you try to write music yourself. I noticed Kit has an amazing memory and can read music at first sight very well. More importantly, he listens to his own playing and to me when I explain something. He not only understands what I mean, but he can do it. And when I tell him one thing in a piece, he will do it everywhere in the piece where it appears again.’

Brendel stops and looks serious. ‘I don’t want to raise expectations. I get upset if newspapers do this. One article called him the future great pianist of the 21st century. It’s the worst thing. You don’t say that in a newspaper. It has caused a lot of problems. Like many talented young players, he can play some things very well, but others need more time and experience. It would be bad if a critic expected perfect playing.’

Now at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed in his life after performing. He says, ‘When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by 50. When I was 50, I had done most of them, but there was still more to do, so I continued. Even though I don’t have the physical strength now, in my mind, there are always things happening, pieces I’ve never played. I don’t play now, but it’s a nice new career.’'

When I was little, I always thought gardens were magical places. My Grandad’s garden was not in a dirty city. It was by a river and gently sloped down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds singing in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – places of peace and quiet. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a greenhouse like some of his neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic patches where glass was broken.

At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn’t without humor, though. He liked to say things like, ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ instead of just saying, ‘I don’t mind.’ He probably wished he had done more with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber. Plumbing wasn’t his passion; it was just his job. He wasn’t very ambitious, though he and Mum once thought about moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. He was very good at fixing things around the house, like making bookshelves or cupboards.

My parents only moved house once. But my mother liked to change the furniture often. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the brass candlesticks on it, but my mother thought they were too fancy and removed them. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister got lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I didn’t get lessons, she said, ‘You’d never have practiced.’

I loved going to the river. I would go there with a fishing net and sandals that were too small, with the fronts cut out for my toes. I’d find a spot to leave my sandals and picnic, then look for fish to catch with my net. After trying to keep them alive at home, I would put them back in the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it seemed unlikely until my father said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.’ My dad might have preferred me to be a carpenter, but I think he hoped things would work out if I tried hard. Even though he didn’t like gardening, he saw how much I loved it and noticed my passion for plants.

Lawrence MacEwen crouches down on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I do the same. A strong Atlantic wind threatens to blow us off the steep cliff and into the ocean 120 meters below. MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, comes up to him, and MacEwen gently strokes him. The wind is strong, but MacEwen feels comfortable here on his island. He is giving me a tour of his neighborhood. Pointing to the north, he shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.’ I see heavy clouds dropping rain on its big mountains. ‘Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.’ Suddenly, MacEwen says, ‘I have sheep to move,’ as rain comes towards us. We walk down the slopes, and he tells me about the island: Volcanic Muck is three km long and half as wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. Moving the sheep stops our conversation. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to gather the sheep but is not doing well. ‘Away to me, Tie. Away to me,’ MacEwen says, meaning the dog should go to the right. But Tie goes straight into the flock, causing confusion. ‘Tie,’ MacEwen says with disappointment. ‘That will never do.’ The dog looks ashamed. The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence runs the farm with his wife, Jenny; their son Colin, who is newly married, manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. ‘They go out and come back only when they’re hungry.’ But island life has its challenges. For example, electricity is only available part of the time. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I find Mary preparing breakfast by torchlight. I get used to it, along with no mobile phone service. ‘There is mobile reception on the hill,’ Mary tells me. ‘Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone in the drawer.’ So I do too. Everything on Muck seems surprisingly nice. Today, the boat brings some groceries and three musicians, who get off with their instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with the islanders tapping their boots to the music. That night, sitting by a warm fire as it rains outside, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. ‘Her father saw a small farm on the isle of Soay in the newspaper and bought it without seeing it. He’d never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.’ Did Jenny know anything about running a farm? ‘She had good typing skills.’ I go to bed with rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food coming from the small island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back through the village and give it to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is very delicious. Also uncertain is my ferry ride the next morning to my next island. In the last two months, many ferries had been canceled because of high seas. If my ferry didn’t come, I’d be stuck on Muck for two more days. Which, now, phone or no phone, was what I secretly hoped for.

Text: 'At first, the game design industry was mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It didn't have many ways for others to join. People often thought of video games as just a hobby for young people, but now the industry is taken seriously. Industry experts are not surprised. Making video games is not easy. Games that come out quickly after a new movie need many team members and months of hard work and skill. Like many industries, it is hard to enter, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, who speaks for an online games magazine, says: ‘It’s hard to make progress in big companies or to influence big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. Not just the directors who lead a whole game, but also the people who design parts of the game.’ So, how can you join this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim disagrees. ‘The only way is to make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t made something. Game design is more a way of life than just a job. Like any creative work, you have to do it to make it real.’ Another expert, John Field, sees other options. ‘There’s a lot to be said for “just doing it”, but it’s more complicated. Many want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs; even fewer have the talent, technical skills, vision, and business ability to really help the industry grow.’ Can you do it alone? ‘Maybe, but it’s hard,’ says John. ‘A good postgraduate course in games can help and give support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and move up. They are interested in all kinds of entertainment and arts. They might have worked a few years after graduation and then decided games are their “thing”. They are not just fans but are excited about the future of games and know about the growing variety of games. Connections can also help. To get ahead in games, you need to network.’ The idea of a young boy always playing games is outdated. Now, games are seen as a grown-up activity. Families often play together on interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is room for growth. ‘Games are popular with large audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see many new opportunities in this area.’

Text: 'Since I was a child, all I wanted to do was play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I'm thankful for that. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always said, ‘You can’t do this, you can’t do that.’ My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play and never played football again. I'm glad it didn't happen to me, but I know it could have been different. When I score a great goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it's not. I have practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. Only by practicing can you score amazing goals. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills. I used to play every sport at school, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know now that education is important, but football was all I thought about then. The teachers did a good job, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, even though he's too young to sit still. I hope he doesn't just want to kick them around like I did. At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so young players could join the first team, but he didn't make a big deal about it. He never said, ‘This is your big chance,’ but we knew it was. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost, and a TV presenter said, ‘You can’t win anything with kids.’ That made us realize how much we had to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team. I rely on close friends and family a lot. But having a lot of money can cause problems. People say, ‘I can’t believe you let your mother keep working.’ I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong and would be upset if they thought they should be on my payroll. My mum doesn't earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. I like using my money to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think, and it doesn't solve everything. After I stop playing, I want to take a year off to do things I couldn't do before. I want to go skiing right after I stop playing. I can't do that now because if I break a leg skiing and can't play football, I wouldn't be insured.'

Text: 'We were living at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to find us a cheap place to live because my father couldn’t write in Los Angeles. Sam was worried about losing clients and money. During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point was not popular with day trippers. The road was not nice, and the nearby resort of La Carmella was more attractive. Only people with little money or those who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people came. After months of being alone, we were surrounded by people and activities. My father was busy trying to write a script and was in a bad mood. Most days, I went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty decided to stay with us. I tried to chase him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I gave him water, and my father threw a boot at him, but not seriously. Rusty knew this and stayed closer. I asked my father, ‘Who do you think he belongs to? He seems to think he belongs to us.’ My father said, ‘You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and often brought me things he found. Sometimes he brought things that weren’t his, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, and I had to return them. He liked to swim too and always came with me, even though I swam faster. He never got discouraged. We had been swimming that day. My father, having finished his script, went to Los Angeles to deliver it. Rusty and I spent the afternoon together at the beach. As the sun set, it got cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. They rode the waves with great balance. One surfer caught my eye. She was very skilled. She decided to stop and rode in on a final wave. ‘Hi,’ she said, ‘why didn’t you join us?’ ‘I haven’t got a surfboard.’ ‘You could get one.’ ‘No money.’ ‘You’re British, aren’t you? Are you visiting?’ ‘No, I live here.’ ‘Is your father American?’ ‘No. He came here to write the film script of a novel he wrote.’ ‘Really? What’s his name?’ ‘Rufus Marsh.’ ‘You mean, Tall as the Morning?’ I nodded. ‘I read that book.’ She looked at me with new interest. People were friendly but only interested when I mentioned Tall as the Morning.'

Violet Hetherington asked herself, "What have I done?" She was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton. The lines were spilling out of the building marked "Departures" to board the Queen Caroline, and none were moving. Her friend Annie had advised her to arrive late, saying, "If you get there too early, you can get bored waiting." Annie, who was married to a diplomat, traveled a lot and often gave advice. But this time, her advice was wrong. After a while, an announcement came over the speakers: there was a "breakdown in the computer system." This made the waiting passengers upset. Some tried to be patient, and a few even tried to stay cheerful, but most were unhappy. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and it might be their last chance for some luxury. The fact that they couldn't even board the ship efficiently was not a good sign. Violet wanted to leave. She looked in her bag for her phone and realized it was missing. This was more annoying than the long lines. It made her feel that going on a cruise was a mistake. Now, she had the problem of the missing phone. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left it in the cab because the number was stored in her phone. Her older son, Harry, always told her to avoid this mistake. Behind her in the line was a friendly-looking couple. "I'm sorry, but I seem to have left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make one call?" Violet asked. She called Harry on the couple's phone and left a message asking him to ask Kristina, her neighbor, to check if the phone was in her flat. If it wasn't there, she would be in trouble because she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, "Thank goodness," but she didn't tell Harry this. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother. Her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding of her mistakes because he made them too. Dan might forget to give the message to Kristina. Finally, the lines started to move, and Violet handed over her travel documents and got ready to board. Her heart sank when she saw the ship's foyer, which looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were shiny fake wood panels, lots of chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets like those in airports. Violet followed the signs to the "Elevators," which were lined with mirrors and full of tired passengers. She was squashed against the side of the lift as it went up, stopping at each floor to let people out. At last, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had asked for. She had been worried about what to say if it didn't. Ignoring Annie's advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she had paid the highest price she could afford to make sure she had a view of the sea.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he didn't know he was about to discover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures for a book about the history of the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a talent for capturing interesting pictures. Since then, Maloof has collected many of Maier’s belongings. In his attic, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked at all of it and realized he had found something special by chance. ‘When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily just sold it all to someone else.’

For some time, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They talked to families who hired her as a nanny and to people at the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier, who was known to be private and a bit unusual, always had a camera with her. She wore large coats, wide hats, and strong shoes. ‘On her day off, she would leave with her camera in the morning and return late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier to care for his daughter. ‘She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’

Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. Although she wasn’t very social, she wasn’t afraid to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she recorded on audiotape. She seemed very dedicated to her ‘second job’ of documenting the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anyone stop her.’ Maier’s work is pure art; she didn’t do it for money. Her photos often show women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. ‘What is interesting about Vivian is that there are so many fascinating pictures,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees the influence of other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her style on her own. ‘Was Vivian very skilled or did she take ideas from others?’

Maloof often wonders if he will ever look through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. The funny thing is he wasn’t interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. ‘As I learned more about photography and looked at her work again, I realized it was the people and street scenes that mattered to her,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to her work than I thought. Now our goal is to make her name known. To get Vivian Maier into the history books.’

Text: 'When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when the book was very popular, but she was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her novel to the officer. The officer looked at it and asked, ‘What’s it about?’ This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are a series of crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past gave more chances for complications and misunderstandings for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I ask how it feels to be successful at a young age, she says, ‘It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels like the success is partly theirs. There’s a family feeling at home, and I got a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.’ Then she adds, ‘What is annoying is when people think I’m not trying to do something philosophical in the book.’ ‘I wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral. Each part was half the length of the one before it,’ said Catton. The book speeds up as it goes. I ask if it matters if the reader notices this. ‘I wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could see them,’ she says. Despite the book's experimental structure, it is still an exciting murder mystery with a gripping plot. Surprisingly, she says she didn’t plan the book beforehand. ‘I would write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be to get out of it.’ It’s clear she also wanted the book to be fun for the reader. We also talk about her love of TV drama series. Thinking of how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue, I ask if she might be interested in screenwriting. ‘That could be pretty cool,’ she says. Her conversation is full of enthusiasm, with a low, secretive laugh. She becomes excited when talking about her work and New Zealand. ‘I always notice when I come to Britain how my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I see why writers move away from New Zealand to busy areas, to be around many people.’ But for now, New Zealand will continue to be her home. I hope it gives her the inspiration she needs for many more novels.'

**Simplified Text:**

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved making things in his dad’s garage and playing the guitar. These two hobbies have been his job for the last forty years: he builds steel-string, acoustic guitars by hand. ‘I’m still amazed by the guitar,’ he says. ‘How can two pieces of wood make such a beautiful sound? And by using different types of wood, you get different sounds. It still amazes me.’ Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a holiday job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I thought if you wanted something, you made it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and types of wood changed the sound, and how to put them together.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny built from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making other things for a long time. ‘We drew model boats and airplanes and then built them, so I knew the process. My father taught us how to use saws, sharpen chisels, and things like that. I’d also been fixing instruments for my friends.’ Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about a career in building guitars. ‘I also liked painting and sculpture,’ he says. After school, he decided to study architecture at university. ‘Architecture involves design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea,’ he remembers. But halfway through, he left the course. ‘I was too individualistic for it,’ he says. ‘But I left with a clearer idea of what I wanted to do. I still liked sculpture, but I realized that building guitars is like sculpture – it’s about shaping sound. And I thought it might be more practical than pure art because you make things people use.’ Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. The first guitars he sold only covered the cost of the materials, but as he became known as a great guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just making a living’. He admits he can only make ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings. In the early years, he worked hard to get known. He went to music festivals most weekends and got musicians to try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments – when musicians asked, he didn’t have an answer because it wasn’t natural for him. Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought the only good acoustic guitars were made in the USA,’ he says. ‘UK-made guitars weren’t seen as real, even though we’ve always had good instrument-making courses and the skills have stayed the same. But now our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.’ Jonny says you can learn valuable techniques in the classroom, and he thinks new instrument-makers should take courses. However, he also believes there is no substitute for trial and error. ‘Look at other instruments, see where people have succeeded or failed, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you’re taught by someone else, you only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’

Text: 'When talking about English conversation, we must start with the weather. This is a tradition, and many writers mention the famous comment by Dr. Johnson, an eighteenth-century diarist, who said, ‘When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather’. This is still true today. Many people try to explain why English people talk so much about the weather, but they often fail. They think English people talk about the weather because they are interested in it. For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not exciting, so he finds the interest in it strange. He notes that England does not have extreme weather like tornadoes or blizzards. On the other hand, English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that the weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that living near the ocean and a continent means you never know what weather you will get. 

However, my research shows that both Bryson and Paxman miss the point. English people do not talk about the weather because they care about it. Instead, weather talk is a way to help English people start conversations. Phrases like ‘Nice day, isn’t it?’ or ‘Ooh, isn’t it cold?’ are not really about the weather. They are greetings or ways to start a conversation. This is similar to how monkeys groom each other to bond socially. 

There are specific times when English people use weather talk. It can be a greeting, a way to start a conversation, or a topic to fill a silence. This means English people use weather talk often, so others think they are obsessed with it. An English conversation might start with weather talk, use it to break the ice, and return to it if there is a pause. This is why people from other countries, and even some English people, think the English are very interested in the weather.'

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was for the Romans to build something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. But they really wanted to know why the Wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. When she couldn't find a historical novel to help explain life at the Wall in Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started a new career as an author in 2001. She felt it was a big change. ‘Teaching is like acting, it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but not as exhausting. My old teaching friends are jealous because I still connect with children through my books.’ Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. ‘Many books for teenagers now are about negative experiences. They are well written,’ she adds, ‘but many are dark or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are neither.’ Alice always tried to teach English and History together, like lessons about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy, and she loves seeing children go from bored to interested. She sees her writing as an extension of teaching. She was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also suggested she try a creative writing course. Alice was surprised. ‘I’d been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me. But I didn’t want to spend my summer holiday doing a course I didn’t think I needed.’ Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction, which she found out just days before leaving. ‘I sat at the computer and created a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.’ Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted. During the course, other students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and he helped edit her novel. Alice says, ‘My mother-in-law thinks we’re rival authors, but I think we complement each other. He works with what I’ve written – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests changing the words. My instinct is to keep adding another scene. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.’

Text: 'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. This race would be man against car, and brother against brother. In the wild Yorkshire Dales of northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. ‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair wore full winter cycling clothes. He wasn’t worried about the cold. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’ The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, 350 metres up. This was no problem for the car, but Alistair’s first miles had a steep 25 per cent incline, so he had a tough start. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair raced on his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny got in the car and started driving. The next time they would see each other was at the finish line. Who would get there first? Jonny’s early confidence was quickly tested. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first problem. A giant tractor came out of a field and onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor was gone, Jonny was back on the road. Alistair was struggling with the slope. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched as he kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, there was open ground. With the sun out, he could show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair picked up speed. In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The villages in Yorkshire are old, and the roads are not made for speed. Jonny tried to drive through a narrow corner. The car slowed down, then passed through a stream on the road. After the last village, the car raced to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped to Fleet Moss, Alistair was crossing his last field and back on the road, coming to the finish from the other side. Head down, legs moving fast… and then he stopped at the line. Alistair looked up. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He raised his arms. ‘Yes!’ Minutes later, Jonny arrived and got out of the car. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said, feeling disappointed. ‘I’m gutted.’'

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds make you feel separate from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make.
