I am so focused that I forget there are millions watching me around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, always told me this was the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not so hard. I was just happy to be there at twenty years old. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe in myself enough. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mind that failed me, not my skills. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, who is a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he even criticizes me when I win. But I was so upset that he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments are more important, and I missed a big one in 2007. Toni couldn’t make me feel better. But he was right. I got another chance. Here I was again in 2008, just one year later. I was sure I learned from that defeat; this time, my mind would not fail me. The best sign that my mind was ready was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, at the house we rent when I play at Wimbledon, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to talk about it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. Until the start of play, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

Text: 'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, ‘I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood.’ She spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain’s National Geographical Society made Jane Goodall famous with articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including children's books and the 1971 bestseller In the Shadow of Man, translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many articles and books tell her life story, but they often focus on her adventures rather than her work. Jane Goodall should be seen as a pioneer in her field and a leading zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know that they have emotions and social systems similar to ours. Her book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study of wild apes in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. When she was five, she disappeared one day. The police and neighbors searched for her. She reappeared with straw in her hair and clothes. She explained that she wanted to see how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours. This curiosity was an early sign of her future as a biologist.'

Text: 'During our first, hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are known to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say lots of medical words.’ Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and many of them probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it than that. You have to make the script come alive for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, thinking of a normal acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a big part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules want to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes many things from educational videos to vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and happy. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists make them.’ She says she got where she is – near the top of her profession – through hard work as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practising your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a love for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a certain kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’'

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people give up these dreams and choose more realistic jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make a living by drawing doodles like those in school notebooks seems silly. Yet, some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. 

For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and showed my drawings to different companies after graduating. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on.

To be a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are not high, but it’s still a tough job. You shouldn’t try to be a cartoonist unless you feel you can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t refuse any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with average talent but good business skills often do better than artistic geniuses who lack business sense.

I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t let others see their work! To protect your work, just draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Text: 'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and clearing out old things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate getting rid of things, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and asked, ‘You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?’ I said I was, but I already felt a bit sorry. He asked if he could have it, and I said ‘Yes’. We went our separate ways. In the years after, I felt sad about what I’d done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. That’s how I felt when I read the email from a man named Keith Rushton, a dealer and restorer of guitars. He said, ‘I’ve got your electric guitar.’ The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell it back to me. I almost cried. I would have given Keith anything he asked for, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad’s habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this story! My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I couldn’t make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Picking it up again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I held it sitting down, then stood up and put a strap over my shoulder because the electric guitar is played standing. My fingers knew where to go. I couldn’t draw a diagram of the chords, but my hands just played them. My fingers felt the pain of holding down the strings. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll have to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe I can play with him. Or maybe there are other people my age with a similar experience. Maybe we could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!'

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them. We often lose dreams when we wake up early. The last hour or two of sleep, which we often miss, is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, where we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM. When people are deprived of REM, they have more intense REM sleep the next night. This suggests dreams are important. When researchers found REM in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought dreams were key to understanding our minds. But later research did not fully support this idea. Now, dream studies focus more on the physical side of dreams. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard University sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study. It showed that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. Pagel thinks this is because creative people use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't all people – like teachers, software designers, and politicians – need to think creatively? Dreams, Stickgold says, help us connect things in new and surprising ways. They help us find new patterns and ideas. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They make unexpected connections, which is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you barely remember, can help you think. On those days, words and images come to me so quickly that I can hardly type fast enough. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Text: 'Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small town by the sea in south-west England. In her studio, you see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leader in the copyist art movement. She can recreate the beauty of a 20th-century impressionist painting or a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait. But she doesn't keep her own work. 'As soon as I finish them, they go,' she says. Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the originals sell for millions, her copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie doesn't usually name her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off. One famous person likes to brag about his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. 'Many famous people pretend my copies are originals,' she says. 'That's their choice.' Some collectors keep the original art in a bank and display Susie's copy at home to save on insurance. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her copies look very real and signs her name on the back. Pretending a copy is the real thing is illegal, and she avoids that. People who make fake art often get into trouble. Susie isn't rich and has had hard times, but her life is more stable now. She doesn't want to risk her reputation. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She earned very little, but it was good practice for her current work and gave her a love for plants. She had to be very precise in her drawings. She has no regrets but is happy to have found better-paying work. When young artists ask for advice, Susie tells them to learn to draw well and be accurate. She has studied a lot to do her work. She can draw plants, make perfect copies of 15th-century art, and reproduce 20th-century abstract art. Now, she focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie says people think modern art is easy, but it's not. Impressionists painted quickly but carefully, and that mix is hard to do well. It's surprising that Susie doesn't create her own art. Isn't art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training, and she earns a good living. She has tried her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked like photos. Susie is a perfectionist.'

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything, except maybe being the fastest on it. She was obsessed with sailing since she was a child. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly wanted to return to the ocean to challenge herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a non-stop, solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and work space for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even the number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was key, she said. She proudly showed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical items. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her think about how we take resources and move on. When I visit Ellen’s office, she finishes a conference call and explains why we must act now to save the planet. She says, "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious and limited. We need to find ways not to use them up." At first, her message was to use less, but now she talks about re-using, like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Sailing seemed selfish compared to this. This is about finding how my voice can help. It really matters."

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and schools to help young people think about a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It’s what makes me who I am. You are connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. My new message isn’t as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I’ve done before."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to inspire them to go outside and try new things. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero'. Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

Some experienced Everest climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agree that a young climber might be physically strong, but they worry if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – we have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father wants him to? Paul says, 'This is not about me trying to be famous because of my son. At first, Jordan talked about doing this later, but we thought: 'Why not now?' We always check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record challenge. This creates a problem for Jordan. People might say that achieving records is more important than enjoying the adventure, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.'

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, you can be pretty sure they’re not listening to classical music. Most of us can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends who Brahms was, they probably won’t know. I have just started a music degree, but the people in my class don’t know more about classical music than others our age. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t have any recordings of it. The numbers must be sad for someone who loves classical music. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical recording sells only 300 copies. I still find that hard to believe. So, why are people less interested in this type of music that has been around for centuries? Older people blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The simple truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know this isn’t true for everyone my age. I know some teenagers who go to classical music concerts often, but they are few. Although I am a musician and play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I enjoy many styles, but looking at what’s on my computer, my classical music is probably close to that 3% figure. So why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Also, experts say we have trouble paying attention for more than about three minutes; too short for most classical music, but perfect for a pop song. Pop is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. The topics of pop music are more interesting than a long piece of classical music with no words. Classical music is powerful, but not full of the issues that matter to teenagers. The way we listen to music has also changed. In the past, families would make music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music you want online, but the music we hear every day is rarely classical. When did you last go into a shop that had classical music playing? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now. Maybe, but I bet not many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but no matter how cool the posters are, I mostly see older people in the audience. I don’t know why people like classical concerts more in middle age, but I do know that if you’re a teenager and your parents love something, you’ll probably try to avoid it. Some say that teenagers don’t like classical music because of schools, but many kids are eager to play classical music in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. Classical music interests them when they perform, but it’s not their first choice when they relax. When we want to relax, it’s always pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to herself. Her mother was getting out of the other door and didn’t hear her. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among trees on a hillside. It was confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," said Bonnie, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be thrown out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. The horses were well cared for, she noticed. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. Lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," said Bonnie, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick. She couldn’t resist riding him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle," she thought. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, to her delight. Busy with putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m serious because I know about horses, even if I don’t know about anything else." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She felt Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old Australian who has become famous for his music. He is known for being quietly confident. Cody started playing the guitar at six and began writing songs at seven. He loved swimming and surfing, and these activities were very important to him. When he was 13, he posted some videos online of himself singing at a school concert. People loved the videos and wanted more, so Cody shared more videos from home. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer and trained with top coaches. But when record companies showed interest in him, he had to make a big decision: stay in Australia to swim or move to the US to pursue music. Cody chose music, even though it was a difficult choice at such a young age. He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. 

Cody and his family moved to the US, leaving behind one dream to follow another. His family supports him but stays out of the spotlight. Cody believes it's important to have good people around you to stay grounded. He sometimes worries about how his decision affects his younger brother and sister, especially since his brother travels a lot and doesn't have a regular life. But his family reassures him that they support him.

Cody's success came from taking a chance, even though it was scary. He now travels to many countries and performs for many fans, which is a dream for many people. However, Cody knows that this success might not last forever.

I jumped out of bed, lifted a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing I could do it. But my grandfather didn’t seem to notice. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. There was fragile ice on both sides, and the dark open water was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pyjamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. A boy I didn’t know. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and reached for my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Better than having a famous grandfather is having this chain, which only he, my mom, and I know about. Plus, I have the diary he kept on that journey. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I patted the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled as I grabbed a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. ‘Can’t you watch where you’re going?’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that clear. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. For a moment, his words hurt like he wanted them to. But I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom appeared with a kind smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’d always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero – from the time he showed me photos of him in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. And yet, a part of me still wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my trip.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa's, but different from his usual work and not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. There was a river in the scene; not one she knew, maybe not even a real one, just a fantasy river. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely visible, just a hint of green, drawing the eye into the pale waters towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, hiding her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? I mean, for him to be so specific. Maybe he’ll add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually to say the muse wasn't being kind to him or that he needed to be nice to the muse for a difficult part. He never suggested the muse was her. She always thought he meant a goddess, not a person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have cut the carpet by itself. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't mean to damage the carpet. I didn't wake up thinking, 'Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.' It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm very unlucky that way. What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! Very small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there: shepherdesses, milkmaids, and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet. I was so excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the one the size of a broom cupboard is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I'll be in my broom cupboard for years. I don't really mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the way the roof slopes down, and the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... Then I had an idea. If I couldn't cut anything off Gran's cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to 'think outside the box'. And that was exactly what I was doing!'

The novel ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly take things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn’t want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' view, not a human one, which made filming more difficult. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimetres to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series was shown, the famous US film director George Lucas called and asked how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully strange. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act at all. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor’s trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was shot with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realising there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was quite successful in showing the magic of the books.

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists that aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the craziness starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be friends, the questions like, "Can you get me free tickets to one of your dad’s concerts?" "Everything’s going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone with this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life on the road and with tutors. So while the rest of the band is staying here for recording, we’re staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who cuts grass. That would be so cool. So normal. I walk into the school’s main office. "Hi, I need my schedule please," I tell the school secretary. "Name?" She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. The secretary seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it’s printing," the secretary says. Then she gives me the paper. English Literature, first period. Cool, I like that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map last night, so I don’t look lost. When I get to the door, I hear the teacher calling names. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes look at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says slowly. "Here." The teacher smiles and says her name is Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she gives us time to talk! All teachers should do this. "So why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many choices. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they pick a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out soon, anyway. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. "He’s an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way." And she doesn’t seem to care. Excellent.'

Text: 'Today, the average American teenage girl is expected to do many things. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being an American teenager is like today. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough anymore. If you don't have big goals, people might think you are lazy. "People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers have these days. We have lots of homework, tests, extra activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life," says teenager Kristen Loose. Even though these stresses are normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist. People in the media often say teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might be like this, it is not fair to say all of them are. "Many people think we spend most of our time watching TV and using our cell phones," Loose says. Loose thinks this is mostly wrong. She keeps her cellphone close, but not just for fun. It helps her and others manage their busy lives. Students today are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable all the time, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their work anywhere. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities now need attention all day, adding to the stress of busy teens. Many teenagers start their day at 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they have to do it all again the next day, often with less than the nine hours of sleep they need. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teens get the recommended nine hours of sleep a night. Also, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are so tired. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time a week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or TV. She uses her energy to volunteer. "I think people believe teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests," Olsen says. Despite this image, Olsen's favorite time of the week is when she volunteers. "I love helping others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community during the week." In 20 years, we don't know what people will think about teenagers, but they will still be proving stereotypes wrong and making the world better. There will be another generation of students who are changing the world, even before they finish school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the last few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project with a twist: it’s part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which is why teenagers like it. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, given by someone from a nearby state, is used to inflate the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chant, and the balloon rises. Some of them run and track it with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There is quiet and a sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside and look at the clear sky. It’s hard to believe you’re just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I watch a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it’s almost the size of a house. Then it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day, using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in the middle of nowhere. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who notes they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is becoming familiar with this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. Then they had to decide whether to drive or walk – it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to others.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountains. And it’s another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. It happened by chance. Her younger brother was very interested in dinosaurs, a phase many children go through, but Chloe hadn't experienced it. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in the field. It amazed her, and she knew she wanted to learn more about it.

I asked Chloe about the support she received because Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous. Chloe was nervous at first, even though Matt was known to be friendly. She worried he might think she was just a kid bothering him with questions. But he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I asked Chloe about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. She admits that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She thinks movies often show palaeontologists as either eccentric geniuses or awkward people who can't relate to others. Films don't show the real work they do.

Chloe explains that her job is varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. She also believes in explaining scientific findings to the public. She thinks it's important to clear up misunderstandings about science and likes to talk to young people to get them interested in the natural world.

Chloe worked on the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs. She says the program makers knew what they were doing, and she was there to give advice if needed. She mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived in the same time period. The program attracted audiences of all ages because it showed dinosaurs in a new, more realistic way.

Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. They remind us that there is still much to learn about the world, and Palaeontology is like a form of time travel.

Text: "I’m going to say this once: when you’re traveling by car with your family, even if you’re six years old, you probably know you’re not ‘there yet,’ even if you keep asking ‘Are we there yet?’ And when you do get there, it’s not ‘there’ anymore, it’s ‘here.’ So, if you think you’re ‘there,’ you should ask ‘Are we here yet?’ I’m sure no one wants to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question over and over during long car trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery goes by outside the window. In the front seat, there’s mum or dad, who gives out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio station, and keeps everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying – like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. What? He can’t do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it’s his other foot, then a hand, and soon he’s in my space and we start fighting. The driver and co-pilot separate us as the car swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his own seat. This calms things down for a while. The scenery continues to pass by. Soon, I’m trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the window isn’t open. Where’s it coming from? My brother is blowing on me. He’s on his side, not touching me, so he’s not breaking any rules. Just breathing? What’s wrong with that? The anger grows. Tim gets yelled at, and there’s more swerving. Then things calm down again – for now. Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. For example, when we ask ‘Are we there yet?’ he often says, ‘Yes. We’re here. Get out of the car.’ ‘But Dad, we’re still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour.’ ‘Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.’ That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you’re finally ‘there’ when the grown-ups get out of the car and move far away from the kids who bothered them for hours. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You’re not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains that they started this business because everyone is busy with phones and gadgets. They wanted to bring people together without screens. The games in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved. Later, 'co-operative' games were developed, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. Pandemic is a Eurogame where players work together to solve global problems. It was created by Matt Leacock from North America, inspired by a game called Lord of the Rings. Leacock loved board games since he was a child, even though he often felt disappointed by them. With his uncle's help, he started designing better games. Pandemic was very successful, and its follow-up version included more storytelling, similar to video games. The growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games because gaming has become normal. Ben Hogg, from a games company, says everyone with a smartphone plays games now. Video games used to be social in arcades or with friends at home, but now they are mostly online, making players feel distant. Some people miss playing games with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that board games are more than just fun. In our online world, they offer a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is growing.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many challenges. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him start playing the guitar. The only radio station he heard at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He says he was 12 before he heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, ‘With tennis, I was at a high level, but it was not what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. It was too much hard work.’ At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents that he wanted to make music his career. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend. In the end, he became successful behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. Fame and fortune did not come. He says, ‘In my own artist career, I’ve often been in the wrong place at the wrong time. But as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he found success. He says, ‘I’d like to think I am one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to.’ This helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that writing with the charts in mind is okay. He asks, ‘Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should write songs that are amazing and likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write number one songs and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. He says, ‘When I go into the studio, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It’s not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.’

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online, but people who don't watch online videos of bike stunts might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist.' This means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online.

I met Tony at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys knew him well, and even older people came to say he is 'an absolute legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, Tony explained what he planned to do, and I wasn't always sure he could do it. But he did, and when I praised him, he seemed not very interested. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he doesn't like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans and prefers doing stunts instead of discussing them.

Tony's fame comes from social media and new camera technology. This technology helps him make a living from what used to be just a hobby. He notices that many people are always looking at screens, but he doesn't complain. He earns well from his videos.

From my experience with top athletes, I know two things are important: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent and help athletes keep going even when they fail. In risky sports, mental strength is very important. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times but got up and tried again until he succeeded.

Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some say he takes unnecessary risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport. They don't know the technical details or that he gets expert advice to reduce risks. Tony is careful about the risks. He says some people never feel scared, but he does. He plans and prepares a lot before trying a new stunt. He needs to be in the right mindset and fully committed before he jumps. If he is, then he is fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found out that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then I did an hour of exercises, with another hour after my day practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen controlled herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterward. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ The experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he wrote a book about traveling around Canada in a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a normal touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally started his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. A serious fever left him in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or the journey home. Yet despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, and my team and I are trying to learn more about water birds, especially one called the American black duck. We have just started using an exciting tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we don't know if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but nothing about their night activities because we didn't have the right equipment before. But this new 'scope' will give us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to take care of the area where they live. It is very hard work. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather hasn't helped – some nights are mild, but more often it is wet. Oh, and it is so quiet that I have needed lots of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one working day so far because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I like the challenge, especially compared to what the summer will bring – hours in a laboratory, where we will look at our results together. It will be hard to be stuck inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But I'm not joking! I spend my workdays eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from the company I work for. Every week, I get samples, small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I keep my colleagues happy by giving them samples! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am at our food lab, and other times I'm out of the country buying raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety and lack of routine in this job, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! People often ask if I get bored of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!'

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air above an amazed audience. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to do different things all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured, or that you might only work for a short time each year. But, actually, the real issue is planning for the future because you can only travel while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many past students start businesses all over the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a job for making money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but great fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or her face, but you’ve probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She helps the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren’t good enough to be lead singers. That’s not true – they have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! ‘What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I’ll be asked to sing,’ she says. ‘It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I’m often surprised by what producers ask for. I was once asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue, I just do the job!’ ‘Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There’s often no written music to look at. I’ll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared: I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already.’ ‘One of my favorite jobs is doing recordings for songwriters. Less experienced writers don’t always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.’

Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge about fashion, but she has built a successful business with her 'satchels' - a traditional bag used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops around the world and are popular with many celebrities. Before choosing to make satchels, Julie considered different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She thought carefully before making her decision. Not everyone agreed with her choice. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She worked with her family from the beginning, especially her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels came from children's storybooks. Although Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, they have been important to her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get more interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in the satchels grew, as did the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is pictured with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie's design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often say there is a positive feeling in her offices – people love working there. There is now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her swimming coach thought she could become a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started joining competitions. Vicky thought it looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was near her school, so she could easily go to training after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, at 28, she stopped competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I got a bit tired of it – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a group.’ The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people aren’t sure if having celebrities is always good for a charity. They say celebrities only do it to promote themselves, which hides the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Her parents were not musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to become more confident. After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert and felt happy. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest, she knew more about music than many others. But Ana felt the teacher didn’t listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about her feelings. She posted it online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the words. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, came from the other side of Ireland to ask her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn’t know the company and didn’t want to be told what to sing. Joss convinced her this wouldn’t happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a great evening. Ana says she likes writing songs about difficult times because there is more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it made him unhappy. Ana hopes people like her songs, but her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an amazing trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He’s a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t. However, I had always wanted to visit the area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could go too, and he finally said yes! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about what needed to be done. But Harry promised he’d taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide said very few people lived along that coast, and on the first morning, we only saw dolphins and birds. There were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was great not to worry about time. We always made lunch or dinner together over campfires. When we fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt stress-free! When it was time to leave, I was sad. How could I return to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I’d miss family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that seeing so many games would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I loved telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually took a book to read instead of watching the games. 

When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two meters tall. Seeing my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, the teacher believed in me more than I did. It took me some time to agree, but a few weeks later, I played against another school. My mum and dad came to watch, which made me nervous, but it was OK in the end!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I couldn’t spend much time with my friends because of all the training, so that part didn’t change much for me. I got used to my new life in the end, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to fix that first. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I thought about different jobs and decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This job involved taking visitors around the city, and I was surprised to find out how much I enjoyed it. I saw the city I had lived in all my life through the eyes of tourists, and it felt new every time! After I finished my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I looked into it, I found out that to get a licence as a full-time tour guide, I needed to know a lot more. All Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. Tour guiding isn’t just about knowing historical facts or making sure you don’t lose anyone in the crowds. You need other skills too. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and you must react to changing situations, like if a place is closed when you arrive or a route changes. Tourists don’t want to hear about problems; they just want to enjoy a well-organised tour. I need to make sure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might post a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I know these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That’s why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job means that my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister Josie. Josie is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary. This is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were all much older than us. We were also nervous because it was the first time we did something like this. In the end, we did not need to worry. One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants.
