Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it very hard work, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their meal. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found this very fun, even if I got wetter than the elephants! My favorite part of the day was the evening. We walked with the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so we did not have much space. We chose this because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not have meat, which we do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff talked and played games. Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I am not sure she is being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself because she missed her friends too much and did not enjoy her time there fully. But when she thinks about it, she knows she was lucky to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I definitely will!

I'm Gina D’Costa and I have a flower shop in the UK. We don’t just sell flowers to people for their friends or homes; many different customers want flowers. Hotels and offices often have flowers in Reception, and sometimes we help with photo sessions for businesses by giving flowers for their advertising pictures. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was really proud of what we did. My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep then, and my friends think I must be crazy, but I love what I do. It’s often colder and darker than I’d like, but that’s normal at that time in the morning, so I don’t mind. The flower market is wonderful, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make choosing difficult. If I was choosing for myself, I’d probably only get pink ones because it’s my favorite color. But I must remember that what I love and what other people want aren’t always the same. It’s not always possible to find the flowers customers want because not all flowers are available all year. I don’t really like arguing about prices with the flower-sellers, but it’s part of the job. Flowers aren’t cheap, so I have to try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and set up vases with the flowers I bought. Then we make bunches of flowers and work out how much orders will cost. Customers are often surprised by how expensive they are, and I sometimes have to ask them to think again about what they’d like. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I like thinking about how I can put together the nicest flowers for the money someone wants to spend. That’s what you have to do when you’re selling things – I wouldn’t want any other job!

Text: 'My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films I want to see, and many films for kids on the weekends. It’s close to where I live, but a year ago, I felt something was missing – talking about a film with a group of people after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema to show the films. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the perfect atmosphere for the film, which was great! Some places we use are even free because the owners make money by selling snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We’re happy to make enough to cover our costs – we’re not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets a bit easier for us, especially now we have our own reliable equipment. We also know how many tickets we’ve sold because everything’s online – no more worries about empty seats! There’s still always plenty to do, but when people of all ages come up at the end to say what a great experience they’ve had, it’s wonderful. The website’s been a great help, and we’re now in contact with other film clubs all over the country. We’ve visited to see how people do things in different places – but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We’ve started a blog, too, because we know that most people now go online for information about films, rather than read reviews in local papers. We’ve also tried putting up a few posters in cafés. Nothing’s as successful as word of mouth, though – people recommending us to their friends. And the audience loves the special activities we do with each film – last month it was a movie quiz, which everybody enjoyed.'

Text: 'Taking photographs was always my favorite thing to do as a child. When I was 15, I wanted to make my hobby more serious, so I decided to do something special. I started a personal project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I put these photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my photos to other people. I was surprised to find out that some people liked how I saw and photographed things. I also enjoyed taking pictures of many different subjects. Then someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be better. I agreed and started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different from what other young photographers were doing—they were taking color photos. Sometimes I doubted my project and almost stopped. But in the end, I trusted my feelings and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher at school. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some of my photos just for fun. I’ll never forget when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I thought my photography might be good enough to work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio and I’ve never regretted my career choice.'

Text: 'I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I knew they did camping and sailing and taught skills like public speaking. These were things I had never done before. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and you are always learning something new. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, run by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you finish each level, you get a certificate. When I first joined, my leader suggested that my first challenge should be helping to organise activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I wasn’t sure it was a good idea because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was quite shy then, and all the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. I decided to take the challenge, but only because I wanted my first NYC certificate. Soon, however, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It meant much more to me than just getting the certificate. When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I had made some great friendships with the children. Now I am there for about four hours a week, and I always look forward to going. Because of what I have learned at the children’s club, I have decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker – someone who works with children. It wasn’t something I had ever thought about before starting at the club. In fact, I had never thought about my future job, and the idea of youth work had never entered my mind. This has been my favourite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my own communication skills while helping others. I have got several other NYC certificates now, and yes, one of them is for camping!'

I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a resort in the mountains, about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was so young that I hadn’t thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to love it too. He made it look easy. In the end, I did well. After this, I quickly started to love the sport and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored of snowboarding, but I love competing and winning. This makes me try harder. I like not having a fixed plan. Sometimes this works well, like when I became the first female to get a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I’d try the jumps that got me this score until I started. That success made me trust my abilities more. In the summer, I focus on training and my studies because there is no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like in the winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends. It helps me deal with not being able to do what I love and am good at. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I think it’s important to have another option in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I wonder if I could become a doctor if I have time for college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I can’t snowboard my whole life.

Text: 'When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I learned a valuable lesson from this. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it. My parents suggested I start my own small business instead. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I found it easier than I thought. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked the idea. Mum showed me how to make nice things at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first jewellery to friends and family. They said they liked them, but I thought they were just being nice. To see if others liked them, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists bought my jewellery to take home as gifts. Soon, people from all over the country called to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just my mum and me at a market stall! That’s when I knew it could work, and I decided to create a website. Since then, I’ve made a lot of money through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It’s been a lot of fun so far.'

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was only 13, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. Being Amelia is partly based on Janine’s life. In an interview about her book, Janine said, ‘Because of my father’s job, my family moved around the country a lot, so I’ve become good at making new friends. I understand what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, starts at a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. As I’m my parents’ only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.’ Janine started her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it seemed natural for Janine to try writing. The year before, she entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was in bookshops. One review of Being Amelia mentions that, even though the book has pictures of happy teenagers on the cover, the people in the story face some difficult challenges, and this makes readers believe in them. The reviewer says that although Janine is still very young, and Being Amelia isn’t a very long novel, she’s shown that she’s a better writer than some other bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: ‘At first, I hid when people recognised me in the street, but now it’s OK. Although I’d like to give advice to other young writers, they have to find what works for them. For me, I know that all I have to do is spend time with my friends, and I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!’'

I'm Tom, I'm fifteen years old, and three years ago my family and I moved to a castle on a small island! It all started when my father was asked to be the castle’s manager. He works for a group that takes care of old buildings and keeps them open for people to visit. He was happy because he thought he might not get such a great chance again, but it took some time before the rest of us agreed that Dad should take the job. We were just thinking about what life on the island would be like – we knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cosy home just across the water, and there was no school. Once we moved, though, we quickly got used to island life. The castle isn’t very beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. The island feels very friendly in summer because lots of visitors come, and there are often parties on the beach. During the winter, we only see the other families who live on the island, and there aren’t as many teenagers among them as I had hoped. The adults all help each other, though, and work on fixing things on the island, which often means lots of hard work. The biggest change for me was traveling by boat every day, back to my old school. I was excited to go on stormy days, when there are big waves – but the ferries don’t run then! And I’ve found out that if I miss the bus to the harbour after school, I also miss the last ferry home, which is worrying. So when schoolmates come home to stay with me, I always tell them to hurry up! But we often get the most amazing views, like when the sun goes down over the sea. Some days, though, it’s so foggy that you can’t see anything, then within hours it’s bright sunshine again – it still seems amazing when that happens, even after living here all this time. Of course, we do get terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to avoid getting damaged. But then I remind myself it’s been here for hundreds of years – and it’s still standing!

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural home. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different bird species apart and find the best places to see them. It was amazing! After we came back home, I joined a local young birdwatchers’ club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I’m almost there. On family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I’ve been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America. I thought I’d see my 200th species there. I wasn’t too disappointed when it didn’t happen because I’ve learned that you have to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fun hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before they introduced me and I walked onto the stage. I knew I’d remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching me! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I’d prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year! I’m lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think that birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, whatever their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other boys and girls. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. However, my family knew I often got interested in new hobbies and then stopped them, so they probably thought the same would happen with football. But it didn’t. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. And the chance came sooner than I expected. I often played in local tournaments, and one of the referees noticed that I was a good player, so he asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she asked me to join her club. I didn’t believe it at first – I didn’t know that young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I started regular training with a big club when I was just 13 years old. After that, I got much better. Even so, people still weren’t sure I’d ever be a star player, which made me feel a bit sad. But the coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself – he even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches, much earlier than I expected! I’ve never run so hard in my life – I didn’t want the other players to blame me for losing. Then, by pure luck, I scored the winning goal. As usual, despite the large crowd, I could clearly hear my coach’s voice cheering me on, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. Fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! And next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The aim is to get teenagers interested in football and to have a chance to talk to other players in my club. It will let them see the professional environment and encourage them to feel they could play for a top team if they’re ready to work hard. But my advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few of those, though – so I’ve been lucky!

Text: 'In recent years, a big change in education in the UK and around the world is encouraging new students to start doing research early in their studies. This idea shows that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists making new discoveries, but it is also a natural way to learn and build skills. Research skills are useful not only in your studies but also in jobs because they help you think about the world and do your work. As a student, you add to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat it; you create it. Creating knowledge means asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? How might that be done? What if this were different? How does it work in that context? Why does it matter? These questions are part of what we call research. Research can be very complex and done by experts, but it can also be simple, like asking questions about everyday things. Most students have done some research before, like for school projects or at work. You have asked questions and done some investigation since you first became interested in studying. You have also used research skills when planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things, training a pet, or shopping online. In college and higher education, having an enquiring mind, finding problems and questions, and thinking critically about information are important learning activities. Some students might find this hard because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as already established, and you learn by listening to teachers and books. It might seem disrespectful to question what is already known, and you might feel you need to be told what is important to learn. But in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australia, questioning knowledge and authorities is important. This might seem difficult, but critical thinking is very important in research. The research of others is useful to students, teachers, and in jobs, but we need to not just repeat what we read. We should think about it, test it, and see if it is logical and supported by evidence. We should not just accept facts and information without thinking critically about them.'

Cities have always been places where people think and create new ideas. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In modern Paris, artist Pablo Picasso talked about art in cafés. But living in a city is not always easy. The same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. Cities are full of creativity, but they can also be stressful and unnatural.

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains. They found that cities can make our thinking less sharp. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees. Even a small view of nature can help our brains because it gives us a break from city life.

More people now live in cities than ever before. Instead of open spaces, we live in crowded areas with many strangers. This can affect our mental and physical health. Walking in a busy city street, our brains have to pay attention to many things: people, traffic, and the city layout. This constant attention is tiring because the brain has to decide what to focus on.

Natural places, on the other hand, don't need as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, created by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He said that being in nature helps our brains relax and recover. Unlike city noises, nature doesn't cause stress. Parks like Central Park in New York give people a break from city life and can quickly improve brain function.

People try many things to boost brain power, like energy drinks or changing office designs, but simply walking in nature is very effective. Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities keep growing. They remain centers of new ideas because the busy city life encourages social interactions, which lead to creativity. Just like 18th-century London, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are successful creative hubs.

The challenge is to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, sometimes people want to leave nature and return to the city.

Text: 'Where should we look for the mind? Many people think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain scans to show this. But I believe the study of the mind should not stop at the brain. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, that objects also play a role in how we think. Archaeology shows that stone tools, jewelry, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and the development of the mind. So, I suggest that what is outside the head might also be part of the mind.

It is easy to see why people think the mind and brain are the same. Most studies on the mind separate people from the objects around them. This is necessary for brain scans, but it often ignores that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I do not deny the importance of the brain, but I believe the mind is more than just the brain. Human intelligence might extend beyond the body into culture and the material world.

This is where my new theory, Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET explores how objects become part of our thinking, like when we make numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool. It also looks at how these processes have changed over time and what they mean for our thinking. This approach gives new insights into what minds are and how they work.

Think of a blind person with a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The stick and the person become one, showing how minds and objects can be connected. The stick helps the blind person 'see' by touch, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. This example shows that human intelligence can change by using new tools. My approach sees the human mind as always evolving.

It is important to remember that, throughout history, tools like stone tools or the internet have been pathways for humans to understand and interact with the world. For humans, tools are used to satisfy our curiosity. This unique human trait explains why we make things and how those things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity – our minds change as they interact with the material world.

MET offers a new way to understand how different tools, from stone axes to smartphones, have shaped and changed our minds. Mind-changing technology might sound futuristic, but humans have used it since they first evolved.'

Text: 'Few inventions have changed the world as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of American culture at every level. It was used in practical and scientific ways, in industry, in art, and for fun and entertainment. Historians say that photography is perhaps the greatest American contribution to the visual arts. No other art form has been as important in the US. This is a big claim, but it shows how photography has become central to American thinking and art. To understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century. Why was this new art so popular? First, photography was a mechanical process, which matched the growing interest in technology. This was part of a national mindset that accepted change as normal. Just like steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes with amazing speed. Second, the camera was the best tool for showing oneself to the public in a country where personal and national identities were always being created and recreated. Third, the camera was important for creating and keeping family memories, even if they were a bit idealized. Finally, the realistic nature of photographs matched the American artists' focus on realism and everyday life. A photograph draws attention to something, showing what the photographer wants us to see. Every picture says, "Look at this!" Because a photograph is made by a machine, it has a unique quality: it is a record of events, people, or things. It shows what was in front of the camera, giving it a sense of objectivity. However, since a person takes the photograph, it also has a personal point of view. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize the subject, which is why photography has been called a 'universal language.' But the meaning of a photograph is more complex. Few things, whether a person, object, or event, explain themselves. No image is shown to us without some context that affects our understanding, like a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a magazine or gallery. To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and role in its culture: Why did the photographer take it? How did people first see it? The same image might be seen in different places and times, and its meaning can change. The camera's importance to artists was once a secret, but now it is well-known. For many years, starting with American artist Andy Warhol, artists have used photographs in their work in many ways. In short, photography has become an important part of art, not against painting, but as a key part of it, essential to our ideas of representation before the camera was invented.'

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, which includes our thoughts and feelings. James was interested in human psychology, which he believed included thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and how we know about these things. Our understanding is personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not be influenced by scientific facts. We often act like amateur psychologists when we give opinions on why people behave in certain ways, like feeling unhappy or quitting their jobs. However, problems occur when people see things differently. Formal psychology tries to find the best explanations for these situations. Psychologists help us tell the difference between personal opinions and scientific facts. 

Psychology studies the mind and brain, but psychologists do not fully understand the brain's role in our thoughts and behaviors. They learn more by studying behavior and making guesses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind is not directly observable. We can only see behavior and make inferences from it. Psychology is like solving a puzzle, using clues from careful observation and analysis. It aims to describe, understand, predict, and control the processes it studies. Psychology helps us understand our experiences and apply this knowledge to improve lives. It has been useful in teaching, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings.

Psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, but scientific study began only about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or looking into one's own mind, to answer questions. They wanted to identify mental structures, but introspection has limits. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only shows a small part of brain activity. William James compared it to trying to see darkness by quickly turning on a light. Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on observing others' behavior rather than their own experiences.

Text: 'In a warehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum shows the other side of consumer culture, where not all products succeed. Here, you can find unusual items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, which were taken off the market because almost nobody wanted them. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and Carol Sherry is in charge. She believes each product tells a sad story about the people who designed and marketed it. 

The surprising thing about the museum is that it makes money. You might think companies would keep their own collections of failed products, but they usually don’t. Many business executives visit the museum because they don’t have their own examples of failed products. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, who used to work in marketing, wanted to create a library of consumer products, not just failures. Since the 1960s, he collected a sample of every new product he found. He discovered that most products fail, so his collection mostly includes unsuccessful ones.

Today’s culture often focuses on optimism, which might explain why these products failed. People in meetings might not have realized a product was going to fail, or they might have ignored the signs. Marketers sometimes spend more money on a failing product to try to make it sell, instead of figuring out what went wrong. This focus on optimism is also common in the self-help industry, where people believe that imagining success can make it happen. 

Neuroscientist Tali Sharot found that people tend to be overly optimistic about their chances of success. Her research shows that well-balanced people often think they have more control over events than they actually do, unlike those with depression. Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen studied whether positive thinking helps people achieve their goals. Her research found that thinking too much about success can actually reduce motivation. For example, people who imagined having a successful week at work often achieved less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck says our beliefs about ability affect how we handle failure. People with a 'fixed theory' mindset think ability is natural and unchangeable, so they find failure very upsetting. For example, a sports star who believes he is a 'natural' might not practice enough and fail. People with an 'incremental theory' mindset believe ability can grow with effort and see failure as a chance to improve. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger after being pushed to their limits. Having an incremental mindset can lead to a happier life, whether or not it leads to success.'

Text: 'Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know the answer, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main reasons are science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what helps players perform their best, and they have many ideas about home advantage. On the other hand, people who invest money in sports wonder why home advantage matters if players are paid well. Shouldn't players feel comfortable anywhere if they earn enough?

What about the fans? Would it matter if a team like Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their passion and support. Fans often think that when they cheer loudly, it helps their team score. But they forget the times when cheering didn't lead to a goal.

However, there is one thing that seems true. Home fans often try to influence the referee. In an experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This matches what happens in real games. Referees try to avoid making decisions that would upset the home crowd.

Studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home football teams in England won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in comfort. Stadiums are also more similar now. Despite these changes, home advantage still varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football. Baseball has the least. This might be because baseball is more about individual players, while basketball and football require teamwork.

Another reason for home advantage might be related to players' testosterone levels. Studies found that players had higher testosterone before home games. This might be a natural urge to defend their home ground. In the Rugby World Cup, some home teams won against stronger opponents by using determination and aggression, showing signs of home advantage. As one referee said, 'It’s the law of the jungle out there.''

Text: "‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said the golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is important to athletes and their coaches. The saying is interesting because its meaning is not clear. Player didn’t really mean lucky; he meant, ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ But how much better can you get with practice? This question is part of the nature-nurture debate: is talent something you are born with, or can you develop it through practice? 

Many people believe practice is more important than natural talent. This idea is supported by psychologist Anders Ericsson, who said that you can become an expert in any field with 10,000 hours of practice. This theory became popular through books like Malcolm Gladwell’s "Outliers" and others that say practice is the key to success. They suggest that 10,000 hours of practice is enough to make anyone an expert. 

However, in his book, Epstein argues that this is not always true. He points out that studies often focus only on successful people, which can be misleading. Epstein explores why some people have certain abilities and others don’t, looking at both natural talent and the environment, support, and determination. His research takes him around the world, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to Alaska. In Alaska, he learns that the husky dogs’ drive in sled races might be partly genetic, suggesting that determination might also have a genetic component.

Epstein talks about the difference between ‘hardware’ (nature) and ‘software’ (nurture) and says that both are important for elite athletes. He does not ignore the importance of training or environment. For example, he suggests that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest runner. But Epstein also shows that sometimes genes are very important. He also discusses race and gender, asking why men and women compete separately if only practice matters. Sometimes the simplest questions are the most important."

Text: 'A recent international report shows that many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so unhappy? In her new book, Kith, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, in front of screens like TVs and computers, and have lost touch with nature – the woods, mountains, rivers, and streams. She believes this is the main problem. This idea matches other discussions about children today. A follow-up study talked to children to understand their unhappiness better. It found that many children would be happier if they could play outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their own childhoods fondly, when they spent long summer days exploring, swimming, or building dens. They think this was healthier than the way children live now. However, they often forget that they are the ones who have made life more protective for their children, worrying about risks. Griffiths’ book has strong arguments. She talks about the fear of danger that keeps kids at home and how it benefits the toy and gadget industry, which sells things to keep children entertained indoors. She also discusses trends like giving medicine to restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. It’s unclear how common these rules are, but Griffiths shares her strong feelings about them. She also talks about childhood freedoms and rules, from fairy tales to school rules. Her arguments are interesting, but sometimes she goes too far. She ignores important counter-arguments and at one point compares modern treatment of children to racism, which seems extreme. Griffiths is very romantic about children. She mostly sees them in a positive way, which might not match real-life experiences with lively young children. She says, ‘children are the musicians of thought,’ but this might not be true for all kids. The main idea of the book is that children should have freedom to explore and take risks. Griffiths thinks kids need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones later. But she doesn’t explain how to ensure these accidents are ‘the right size.’ Also, not all children might want the adventurous life Griffiths describes. What about the quiet and cautious children? Maybe the real mistake is forcing all children into the same lifestyle, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.'

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not because of my education. Most life problems cannot be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the value of play for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young. Those that have more to learn play more. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, moral lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is important for economic success. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems, not just follow instructions or do routine calculations. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate problems, we will have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his work 'combinatorial play'. He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam. We cannot teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling that focuses on set questions and answers. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring for them, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit. If you cannot quit, it is not play. Players know they must keep others happy to continue playing. This makes play very democratic. School has become harder: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and there is more pressure for high grades. Outside school, adult-led sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must intervene instead of letting children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They are due to social factors like parents' fears, experts warning about dangers, less cohesive neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the trend of the last fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They must be allowed to play and explore so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to contact potential employers directly. This is similar to standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, with more access, there is also a higher chance of making mistakes.

For example, a young jobseeker in the US contacted a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts that the jobseeker thought could help him get a job. But the executive was not happy with this request. She did not want to share her contacts with a stranger and sent a harsh rejection note, which became very popular online. Many people who saw the note were shocked, and the executive might regret her tone. However, this incident might help young people think more carefully about using social media for professional purposes. It shows that social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly.

There is an irony here because social media sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of young people's social lives for years. When my generation was young, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to impress others and try new things. It was often based on fantasy. You could talk to someone online for hours and then ignore them at school. By choosing certain pictures or songs for your Facebook page, you could become a different person. But when using social media for professional networking, this experience can be a problem. Some young people do not see the difference. We first became popular online by being bold, which might be why some still think this is a good idea. Just because many people liked your Facebook posts, it does not mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you are worth hiring. We need to understand that what we learned about social networking as teenagers does not work in the job world. We must meet employers' standards to succeed.

One common complaint from employers about young job seekers on professional networking sites is that they are too familiar and seem arrogant. This makes older generations think of us as an "entitled generation." In reality, many young people are desperate to find jobs, which is why they turn to social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable workers.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach gives you a better chance of getting a positive response. Avoid sending impersonal emails and keep a humble tone to avoid offending the recipient. Remember, social media can be a great way to make useful contacts, but it needs careful handling to avoid closing doors.

Text: 'Anyone who says they can predict the future of newspapers is either lying or foolish. If you look at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. The Pew Research Centre in the USA says that newspapers are now the main source of news for only 26% of US citizens, compared to 45% in 2001. Many people predict that the last printed newspaper will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist said that books and theatre were finished and that newspapers would become the most important form of social life. But theatre survived newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has done well in the TV age, and cinema has stayed popular despite videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have become popular again, with online sales up 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media too, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This happened because it became possible and affordable to produce news for many people in the mid-19th century, thanks to the steam press, railway, and telegraph. Also important was the idea that everything is always changing and we need regular updates, which was not common in medieval times. Now, we expect change. To medieval people, the only certainties were the seasons and disasters like famine, flood, or disease, which they couldn't predict. Life was seen as cyclical, with important truths repeating. Journalism as a full-time job only started in the 19th century. Even then, there was no clear reason why people needed news regularly. Regular newspaper publication can be a burden. Online news readers can check news whenever they want. Search engines and algorithms let us personalize news to our interests. When big stories happen, internet news can update minute-by-minute. Mistakes can be corrected quickly. There are no space limits, so stories can be detailed, and documents can be accessed in full. This is very different from newspapers. However, online news often focuses on being first, getting reader comments, and creating excitement, which can add to confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. In some ways, we are returning to that. Newspapers have not always been good at explaining how the world works. They might face extinction. Or, as the internet adds to our feeling of living in a chaotic world, newspapers might find that they can guide us to understanding.'

Text: 'If humans were truly comfortable under the light of the moon and stars, we would enjoy the darkness, just like many animals that are active at night. But we are daytime creatures, with eyes made for sunlight. This is a basic part of who we are, even if we don't often think about it. It's why we have changed the night by adding light everywhere. This change, called light pollution, has effects that scientists are just starting to understand. Light pollution happens because of poor lighting design, which lets artificial light shine into the sky instead of focusing it on the ground. This extra light changes the natural darkness of night, affecting many living things, including us. It can disturb migration, reproduction, and feeding. In the past, the idea of 'light pollution' would not have made sense. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the world's largest city. Nearly a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few houses had gas lights, and there were no public gaslights in the streets yet. From a few miles away, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. We have lit up the night as if it were empty, but it is not. Many animals are active at night. Light is a strong force and attracts many species. For example, birds can be drawn to bright lights and fly around them until they are exhausted. Birds migrating at night can crash into tall, brightly lit buildings. Some birds sing at strange times because of artificial light. People used to think light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need a clear night sky. Most of us don't need a perfect view of the stars for our work, but we do need darkness. Darkness is important for our health, just like light. Changing our natural sleep patterns can cause health problems. The regular cycle of day and night is important for our well-being. Changing these rhythms is like changing our balance. In the end, humans are affected by light pollution just like animals near bright lights. We have lost touch with our natural and cultural heritage – the stars and the natural day-night cycle. Light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe, which we can best understand by looking at the night sky with the Milky Way above us.'

The founder of a big international company recently said that his company will stop keeping track of employees' paid holiday time. This idea was inspired by an internet company with a similar policy. The founder got the idea from an email from his daughter, which was shared in many newspapers. Some people think this announcement is just a way to make the company look good, but is the idea practical?

The internet company and the big international company are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the big company has 50,000 employees and many different services like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's work better. 

The founder of the big company said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work and team are up to date and their absence won't harm the business or their careers. But is it possible to be that sure? Even if you prepare before a holiday, there is always work waiting when you return. This might make employees feel guilty about taking time off, leading to stress and lower productivity.

There could also be pressure from colleagues about who takes time off and for how long. In the corporate world, there is a culture of working late, and this could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave. If employees don't feel safe taking leave, they might not take it at all, or they might stick to their legal rights, making the policy useless.

Modern technology blurs the line between work and free time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees asked how this new way of working fit with the old time-off policy. If the company can't track work hours, why should it track time off? But if there are no set work hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might feel watched all the time, leading to stress.

Employment laws exist to ensure workers get enough rest for their health. The benefits of the unlimited leave policy, like better morale and creativity, can happen without affecting worker well-being. So, I am not sure if "taking as much holiday as they want" is really the goal or the likely result of this policy.

Text: 'Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in the same field check a scientific research paper. It is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research. This process is supposed to stop flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. Scientists often mention it to assure the media and the public. Reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to ensure trust in published research? The answer is both yes and no. Looking into these issues shows a lot about the current state of scientific publishing, which is changing. I am not ready to give up on journal-based peer review. I still think all papers should be checked before they are formally published, but I feel changes happening. The growing use of preprints (drafts of papers posted online without peer review) is an important part of this change. Preprints help share new results quickly so they can be read, critiqued, and built upon. Publishing in journals has become more about fame and career growth, which affects the motivations of authors and reviewers. Competition for spots in top journals pushes scientists to do their best work, but it also encourages cutting corners. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is good enough for a journal, not just if it is good. For top journals, this can depend on how newsworthy a paper is, not just its scientific quality. These problems are known, but few people want to change the system. However, as biologist Ron Vale recently argued in a preprint, preprints might be a way to solve these issues because they don't require a big change from the norm. Preprint archives have existed for twenty years, but they are not used everywhere. This slow adoption is partly because scientists are cautious and because many think journals won't accept papers that have been posted as preprints. There is also a fear that publishing without peer review will lead to 'junk science,' but this hasn't happened yet. Preprints are not peer-reviewed, but authors know they will be critiqued by a global community. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, says: ‘My paper was a critique of another paper, which is hard to do in traditional journals. With anonymous peer review, the original authors might block a critical paper, or they might not be chosen as reviewers and could complain about misrepresentation. By posting a preprint, the original authors could respond, and we could consider their points. All comments are public, so readers can judge the quality of the arguments. Rejection by journals is less of a problem because the preprint and comments are still available, so our work is not wasted.’ Preprint archives allow global scientific discussions that used to be private. They can also be a place for negative results, which are important but often ignored by journals focused on new discoveries. Preprints increase how often papers are read and cited, showing their effectiveness. By using the web's openness and the collaborative spirit in science, preprints can help focus on the work itself, not just where it is published.'

Text: 'When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say it is like ‘a painting in words’. Their answers rarely satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group to choose an object and write one paragraph describing it like a scientist, and another from the point of view of the object itself, called ‘Poem.’ Here’s what one student wrote: Poem I may look strange or scary, but I’m a device that helps people breathe. I’m only used in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need me. The item? An oxygen mask – a surprising choice that helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise led to fun and useful discussion. When I was in school, poetry didn’t make much sense to me. I saw every poem as a confusing puzzle that blocked true understanding and feeling. After school, poetry becomes something most people care about less and less. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not like regular writing. It almost dares you to read it, and often you feel disappointed because it seems plain or hard to understand. Still, you feel good for trying. What do we hope to find in poems? Aren’t poems places for deep feelings, beautiful images, gentle thoughts, or sharp humor? The answer might be yes. But if we want tears, we watch movies; for information or strong opinions, we read online articles. Novels let us escape to other worlds, paintings please our eyes, and music – well, nothing beats the mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody. However, one thing a poem can offer is ambiguity. Everyday life – unlike reading sentence by sentence – is full of it. But these ideas still don’t tell us what a poem really is. If you search online for ‘poem’, it leads to ‘poetry’: ‘a form of literary art using the beauty and rhythm of language.’ This is fine for English professors, but it hides the word’s roots. ‘Poem’ comes from the Greek poí?ma, meaning ‘a thing made,’ and a poet is ‘a maker of things.’ So if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes say poems are like wild animals – untameable, unpredictable – or like machines – carefully made and precise – depending on their view. But these comparisons don’t always work. The best part of trying to define a poem through comparison is not the comparison itself but the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It can help us think differently and see common things in a new way. The poem as a mental object is not hard to imagine, especially if we think about how song lyrics can get stuck in our heads. The mix of words and melody is powerful, like schoolyard rhymes such as ‘Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me.’ But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a page of a newspaper or magazine, looking right at you: A poem can hit home like nothing else, even though, in terms of ink on paper, it does nothing more than the prose around it. What about all that empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or ad? A poem is made by writing and rewriting just like an article, story, or novel, but it never really becomes what they usually are – something made to be sold. Publishers write press releases and send out review copies of poetry books, but few expect a book to pay for its printing costs. A poem shows itself not as something for sale, but as something for its own sake. Because of its special place – set apart in a magazine or book – a poem can still surprise us, even if only for a moment.'

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money, and it might have been better to spend it on something useful for the house. Still, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I found made me happy because it felt like connecting to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. But it was raining, so I chose a closer spot that mostly had old farming tools. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it but couldn't leave without checking. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a round, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, detailed loop. I stopped and stared, then remembered to breathe. It looked like the Great Torc, a famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a beautiful necklace of gold and silver, with a gold ring at each end, just like the one I found.

I took it to the car and kept looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in ages. ‘Marion!’ I called, ‘I've got something for you.’ She came in, stopped, and asked, ‘What is it?’ I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been robbed, but I was anxious. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.

The law says you must report such finds within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as possible before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I put the torc on his desk. He turned, still talking, then stopped mid-sentence. The torc was checked and later sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find. It's something I've saved for the nation. People ask me, ‘Now that you've found something amazing, will you stop detecting?’ But those brooches and coins are still interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn't stop fishing. There's always the chance of a bigger fish tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things to do when I travel, but I don't talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends tell me about their busy travel plans, full of activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. What would they think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rain and lazy mornings in Italian beds? Better sleep is a nice part of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. There were noisy birds nearby, but it didn't bother me. Away from home, I could sleep deeply and have vivid dreams. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes easier. But I think travel sleep is different because it is part of the travel experience. When we travel, we see, hear, and smell new things. We take in new cultures, music, and landscapes. When we sleep, we process all this new information. That's why sleep feels more intense when we travel. Sleep also changes with different places. People worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local habits is harder than changing time zones. On the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is just one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to their sleep pattern. Once I do, I feel like I truly belong there. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, everyone slowly stopped talking and went to rest on hammocks and sofas. I realized why there were so many pillows on the floor. I joined them and experienced the Latin American custom of the siesta. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is special because I remember it. Away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds in my sleep. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said to her customer politely. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking unhappy. "But it is so boring," she said. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little hat will make me stand out." She patted the red and black small top hat on her head. "Yes," she said, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change the woman's mind. Smiling, she agreed that the woman would stand out at the wedding. Mia thought of her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen's thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since everyone was together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious to meet Jen's friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia's husband, Jeff, had said, "Tattie? What sort of name is that?" Mia replied, "It's short for Tatiana. I think it’s nice." Jeff thought it sounded too fancy. He didn't like anything showy and always spoke his mind. He wouldn't have hesitated to tell the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said a trash can lid would look better on her. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite." An hour later, Mia closed her shop and went home. Her commute was only forty seconds because her shop was in a converted barn next to their house. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to turn the barn into a space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think people want hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends that there was a demand for hats for special occasions. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her showroom in the village of Little Pelham. In a relaxed and friendly place, they could try on many hats to find the right one. Mia encouraged customers to bring their outfits to make sure everything matched. She recently started selling handbags and costume jewelry too.

Text: 'Lawrence Okoye has moved from London to Atlanta, USA, for a new part of his sports journey. He is confident but surprised by how far he has come—from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major American football team. Lawrence has never played American football before, but he might be chosen for one of the top teams. In Atlanta, he is learning about his new position in the sport. It seems unbelievable that a 21-year-old from London could be picked for a big American team, but Lawrence is used to surprising people. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on discus instead. In just 20 months, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training to prepare for the world championships. He says, ‘American football was in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. I thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then.’ After arriving in America, he read about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, he thought he might be good enough to try out. ‘Pretty much,’ he says. ‘I went on the site and applied.’ Was he nervous about competing with experienced players? ‘No,’ he says. ‘I don’t get nervous for many things.’ Lawrence is confident in his abilities. His performance in tests and drills made him stand out as the most impressive player. ‘I was very happy to hear that,’ he says. But he knows he has a lot to learn. How can someone with no experience make it into an NFL team? ‘Coaches say I have the right skills. It’s about how hard I work,’ he replies. Is he worried about being selected? ‘I’m not. There’s no pressure on me. People say I’ll be picked, but I’m not too worried.’ This calm attitude might come from his Olympic experience, where he finished last in the discus final. He has moved on from that and is proud he made it to the final. ‘That was an amazing day,’ he says. ‘The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s sport. I can return to it.’ After the Olympics, some thought the experience affected him. Lawrence doesn’t comment on that. An NFL player earns at least $400,000 a year, so the money is a big reason to try. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. Should he focus on one sport? ‘I understand why people say that,’ he responds. ‘I’m trying to achieve a dream I had as a schoolkid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to discus, which I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought through.’'

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, although it was mid-September, it had not yet started snowing in Siberia. I could see no sign of human life, and the view stretched out with mountains, streams, and forests to an endless horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to a remote area to sell safety clothing to the local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with the help of a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with only a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it these days. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unconvinced and said one word, "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I didn't mention that I was on a tight budget because my trip was self-funded. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. I was not sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman’s over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking hard about a particular question. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy writing, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. It was six years later that I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still far from having full control of my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug in a big way after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: to cycle around the world. Ever since that first ride we took together, Al had been setting himself greater and greater challenges. This round-the-world-by-bike trip was certainly his greatest so far. At times he thought that the ride, or the road, would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could deal with each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the people who said he could not do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

Text: 'In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns to race through a series of pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to see what it feels like to take part. An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first said I was in good health, and the second said I would empty all my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I also learned that I would need to stay oriented. ‘The horizon is your best friend,’ I was told, ‘the pilot will explain which way to look.’ I was also asked to promise that when flying upside down, I would ‘completely relax. Try and enjoy the view.’ Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything. By the time we were moving down the runway, my legs were up in front of me, feet trying not to touch the important steering pedals, hands trying not to touch any of the many important switches, my mind was made up. Ignoring all instructions, I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is the difficult part of high-speed acrobatic flying. To survive without passing out, you have to stay calm and focused. You have to tense up at the right time and relax at the right time. Panicking is a bad idea. None of this was comforting as we started going down the runway. Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway. We were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the world’s fastest acrobatic planes, ready to go. The plane took off and two seconds later we turned sharply to the right. It was a quick, strong move and I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed everything, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned sharply left and dived, leaving my stomach at 2,000 meters and my lungs pressed against the roof of the plane. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, aiming for the small space between two pylons. They passed at 400 km per hour but my moment of excitement was taken by a sharp right turn. We hadn’t even done any acrobatics yet. For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane, my hand shaking so much the plane shook too… it’s that responsive. Then Dario said something. I said, ‘Can you repeat that?’ But instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. ‘Are you okay?’ ‘Yup.’ ‘Have you had enough?’ ‘No,’ I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane up and over, turning a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was a bit much. At the top of the loop, as we were flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, ‘Relax, relax, look up.’ Then I looked up and saw some fields. The flight was over in 10 minutes. It had been ‘soft’ compared to what the pilots endure when they race. To show this, Dario got out some sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily ate. I didn’t eat for hours and that night I dreamed of doing the loop the loop over and over again.'

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you’ve ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. He says his perfect temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned about surviving in cold places. His big opportunity came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. ‘I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realised that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.’ He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. ‘I started at a good time. When I began, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. You had coral people, elephant people, chimpanzee people. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed.’ The camera and communications technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. ‘It is certainly easier to film today. If you shot something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You shot less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.’ ‘My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.’ Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy job. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very hard. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. ‘We find a new hole and wait. We move around to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim in very cold water and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for a new expedition that he says is even more challenging. Explorers are confident and determined people. They need to be. This time, there is much more at risk.
