Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre journey to the North Pole, taking detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and he knows the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar region. This is a job he was trained for. When he was a child, Pen was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous polar explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tougher by sending him out into the Scottish mountains in blizzards with as few clothes as possible. His father gave him a love for frozen adventures, and Pen had unusual physical strength. Pen is married to Mary, who loves horses and the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he’s at home: ‘He’s in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he’s somewhere in the Arctic.’ For fun, she once raced against him in a famous mountain event where riders on horseback compete against people on foot. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. ‘It’s much harder to be away from them this time,’ he admits. ‘They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in the way I said goodbye. I told my son, “You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister.” He took it seriously, asking his mum how she was all the time, but it was too much for him. It was well-meaning, but unfair.’ For similar reasons, he plans to have very little contact with them while in the Arctic. ‘If you call them, you remind them how far away you are.’ He is spending these last days before leaving preparing his equipment carefully. ‘Out on the ice, you can’t fix things easily or do anything that isn’t simple,’ he says. With him will be Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and the expedition photographer, Martin Hartley. They will have a team of six flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for someone like him, says Pen, and he is also thinking about something else. ‘I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I’ve done far less training than I’m comfortable with.’ Why? ‘Organisational things always seem more urgent. So I’m almost afraid of what I’m going to ask of myself.’ Pen believes his mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge that inspired past explorers. ‘Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal,’ he admits, ‘and not very useful to anyone outside the polar adventuring community. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we’re trying to involve as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it,’ he says. ‘Our skills, which are usually strange and not needed in society, have become very important. Suddenly, we’re useful again.’

Text: I had a 'year off'. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. These activities were great, but I missed having a big competition. I wanted to stay fit in case I wanted to try for the Olympics again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's invitation: 'Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?' I love rowing and missed it, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. I knew if I joined the race, I would want to win. Would Ben help me win? Probably not. But being an underdog with no pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to do the race anyway and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat, making the race possible. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would take work. I also had to think about losing money from not working. Speaking at business conferences is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete. It's nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would mean I could talk about something new: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to be thankful for the easy life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but it was straightforward. I trained all day nearly every day, but the program was set, with doctors and dieticians. I worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I was afraid it would look like I just wanted to be on TV. My worries went away during our preparations. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about the mind than just rowing. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and a year on a deserted island. But he couldn't row. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to show Ben the big improvements he needed. I should have known his level when I agreed to race with him.

Text: 'Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in the far north of Finland. At 26, I was feeling restless. I was dreaming of cold and empty Arctic landscapes, maybe because of the noise and crowded life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to let me work as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, many tourists come for sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow. These rides can last from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place – the 'wilderness farm’, which they said was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away. November 6, London On my flight, I look at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I am supposed to learn their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the page down and look out of the window instead. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. But I think I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and the rivers freezing. November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrive at the farm after dark and am given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to start right away?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which becomes very loud by the time I reach the dogsheds. Three people are running back and forth, getting the huskies ready and attaching them to sleds. The dogs are very excited, pulling hard on the ropes because they want to go. I can barely hear to introduce myself, and the others are too busy to talk much. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light. November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I am asked what I can do for the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I don’t know. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never used an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and giving water to the dogs become hard in the cold. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds – and from being dragged around by very excited huskies. But I feel proud. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’'

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would allow her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious about a natural treatment she used, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after she had an accident with a bike while training. Radcliffe says the achievement never really felt real to her. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but at the time, it just felt like what she was meant to do. Her team had a motto: no limits.

During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up the fast pace, fearing she might drop out. Hartmann was upset by this, but he understood why someone might think it was risky. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast and still sprinted the last part in 2 minutes 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run quicker than that.’ The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn’t expect anyone to beat that time soon, but Radcliffe thought she could do it again next year. Unfortunately, that didn’t happen.

After the race, people wondered how Radcliffe, with her awkward running style, beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with her for weeks, helping her manage the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, ‘I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle pain like her. She would push me to work so deeply into her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward.’ Hartmann described traveling 13 hours to her training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, ‘Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting.’ There was no time for a break; she was ready for a two-hour session. Hartmann said, ‘Paula would get every last bit of effort from you. That's what made her so good.’ During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that other athletes felt neglected.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has beaten her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany might do it. Maybe it's because people race each other more than themselves.’ What does she mean? ‘I always pushed myself, even when I was winning. I never relaxed; I always kept pushing hard.’ Radcliffe didn’t know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She never ran as fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

Text: 'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, came out, I didn't know how people would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' in Britain. I believed our show was a new and exciting part of that, but I was still worried. Would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques, but also history, memories, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was a success and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my restaurant experiences. Each project feels like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often a real one, with travel and meeting new people. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest book, where you travel the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best golden pasta. These people have spent years trying to reach their own idea of perfection. Perfection is different for everyone. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was hard, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was not included. But after long meetings, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of what is perfect, based on their feelings, memories, and surroundings. I knew from the start that I wouldn't say the recipes were the 'best'. But I thought that by using my skills and talking to food experts, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through trying new things. The TV series let me explore foods, people, and places I had never seen before, and I was excited about that. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included visiting a factory that processed the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that was not good enough to film. To perfect each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow, using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burning my house down trying to make a Neapolitan-style pizza.'

Text: 'We were still hours away from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and went off the road into a field. It stopped suddenly. John got out and opened the front of the van to look at the engine. He stood there for a long time, looking like he knew what he was doing. But then he said, ‘Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,’ and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, ‘We can’t stay here forever,’ she said. The field was big, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. ‘No, we can’t stay here forever,’ I said, agreeing with Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We sat by the road and watched John walk away to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay on the grass. ‘Tell us a story,’ she said. Bea lay down next to her. ‘Go on, tell us a story.’ So I told them about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I told them what the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and a fight over a worm. ‘That’s silly, no one understands bird language,’ Bea said. My eyes hurt. ‘I do.’ But my voice didn’t sound sure. ‘Liar.’ I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I was. ‘Mum…?’ But she was asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind. They waved and smiled at her through the windows. We followed John into a café near the road, not far from where our van was parked. ‘It’s a hotel,’ John whispered. ‘It might be expensive.’ ‘We’ll just have some tea,’ Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. ‘It’s like syrup in there,’ she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked at the engine. ‘It’s amazing it got us this far,’ he said when it got dark. Mum put blankets on the ground for us to sleep in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn’t moving. ‘I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,’ John said. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled by a rope with John driving it. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we’d get home since our van needed to be pulled everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I fell asleep.'

Lucy was at the welcome party in the hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like Lucy. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city. Lucy didn't hear her name clearly because of the noise, but it was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy. They spoke English well enough to talk about the music they were playing, where they had traveled recently, and where they were going next. 

‘I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,’ Lucy told them. It sounded impressive. But Lucy didn't really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She didn't want to do many of the things that filled her time: the concerts and competitions that took her around the world. She missed so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she made it. There was a party. Lucy’s dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her, and her little brother Gus imagined himself at the same festival one day. Grace Chang, her teacher, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The thing was, Lucy hadn't even applied. Her mother had filled out the form and sent in the CD. ‘I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,’ her mom had said. Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want to give her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy thought that causing trouble was the worst thing a person could do, and she didn't even think about trying to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned forward as if he had misheard her. ‘Tanglewood?’ ‘Yeah.’ ‘How old are you?’ ‘Fifteen.’ He exchanged a glance with Liesel/Louisa, who said, ‘Wow.’ Lucy hadn’t meant to brag. It was hard to know the difference between sharing her achievements to fit in and showing off. ‘It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're going to try...’ ‘Excuse me,’ Liesel/Louisa said, looking across the room as if she saw someone she had to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed. ‘Have you ever been to Japan?’ He had long, shaggy hair, like many guy musicians, to show they were music nerds but also rebels. ‘Once. When I was, like, eight.’ He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather appeared at her side. ‘Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.’ He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. ‘And don't get too friendly with the competition.’ ‘They're not the competition.’ ‘Everyone is the competition.’ Her grandfather took her around the room and made her talk to everyone he thought was important. Lucy smiled and nodded a lot, hearing about half of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after they left the party, her grandfather turned to her. ‘You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are.’ She did like that part. Being somebody. Even if it meant some people were jealous or thought she was too young to get the kind of attention she did. Being a concert pianist didn't win her any special respect from the kids she’d been at school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know and wouldn't care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro well. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.

Text: "‘It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,’ said Dad. He’s hard to argue with, so I decided to see what experts say – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a good sense of who they are, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says ‘social networking is a big part of modern childhood. Teenagers don’t just use media for things like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do – they live in it. It’s not good or bad – it’s how you use it that matters.’ How does our social networking compare with what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like hanging out at the youth club, as today’s parents did when they were younger, to share jokes and gossip: a kind of virtual youth club. It helps teenagers develop a sense of identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and get along with their peers. Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time when you ask, who am I? Social networking can help you find that self-identity: you can post about your favorite music or sports, discover what you enjoy, and see that other people have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He says that using social media can help if you’re shy: ‘Talking online can be easier than face-to-face, and you can practice social skills in a less scary environment.’ Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He thinks they can help if you’re quiet and have a special interest because they let you connect with others who like the same things. ‘If you’re one of only three people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of people who like the same thing, you can still be popular, just in a different way,’ he says. Pauline White, a digital education expert, told me something interesting: ‘It’s people your age who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded people, and create their own content who are really using the power of social networks.’ She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about things that interest them. Photo-sharing sites, she says, are changing creativity. Keen photographers can connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interest. ‘This all helps with getting jobs and will be useful in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness – and you need to understand how it works to create customers. For example, if you make a product and have 1000 friends on different social networks, they’re all potential customers. If you link all those networks, there’s your customer base.’ Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and start working, agrees Matthews. ‘One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create content and share it. Collaboration is a real 21st-century skill and important for being employable in a digital age.’"

Text: 'When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they probably don't think of a long trip through nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. But my parents wanted something different for our summer vacation this year. My dad planned what many teenagers might think is a nightmare: a big family trip. "Not enough people do this anymore," my parents said before the vacation, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a reason why!" In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With just enough space left for us in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our big home for smaller places to stay over the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into. We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under very dark, starry skies, but only after almost being blown off the highway in a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way! The next day, we got up early and started driving again. I noticed a pattern. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to feel the same, but each adventure was different. We walked on the Great Sand Dunes and went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. As we climbed to our next stop, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new. We got used to traffic from road construction. We laughed when we saw the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common, and our close encounter with a bear and a worried park ranger gave us unforgettable memories. As we continued, life at home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its problems, didn't ruin our excitement. It was a 95-year-old building with no internet or cell phone service, but it had the most amazing views. After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to a faraway place to find something special. It was both happy and sad to be home again, but at least I didn't fight with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our trip to look through and remember. For me, the best memories were the unplanned and spontaneous moments.'

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay because it was her final year. Amy was happy because she got the best room at the college, with a kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still watch over Amy, even if she didn’t like it. So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. Rose only had vague holiday memories of her grandmother and never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose’s parents were not very excited, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to know her granddaughter again. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Rose was ten years old when she last saw her grandmother, but her memories were happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked bringing people together. Rose expected dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. This made Rose smile. Her grandmother was not a typical old lady and seemed to go to more social events than the Queen of England. Dahlia and Rose talked before the move. Rose was sensible and mature. She knew about healthy eating, exercise, and sleep. But Rose wanted independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, or go out without asking permission every time. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood. Rose’s mother gave her a new touch-screen phone with a video camera for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed it would be about trust. Her grandmother would trust her to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were problems, they would talk about it. Rose was never a wild child. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and start her life again. It was her fourth school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this was the last time because she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed difficult. When she was 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Now, that novel is about to be published. Charlotte told her old teacher, who was surprised because she thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait if she could do it now.

I met Charlotte in the office of her publishers. Even though I knew she was 15, I was surprised to see a teenager there. Her book is impressive: the story is strong and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of the main character, shows it was written by a teenager. A public relations person was with us in case Charlotte needed help, but she didn’t. Charlotte is confident and smart, but also calm. She knows she is young and says, ‘I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share,’ she laughs. ‘I don’t think my age limits my understanding, but I’m not very wise either. I wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility.’

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are shown in books. She says there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who isn’t socially skilled. She found these types annoying. ‘What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who are okay. Some writers make it seem like teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, and this can hurt their confidence.’

Charlotte loves reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. ‘These books explore deep ideas about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I could do it.’ She does like a book called How Not to Write a Novel. ‘It says if the reader can guess what happens next, the suspense is gone.’

Some might think Charlotte’s parents, who are journalists, helped her get published. Her father knew someone in publishing who read her book first. She knows she was lucky because getting a first novel read is hard, no matter the author’s age. ‘Every writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, it’s up to your talent,’ Charlotte says.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping, wanted to show he knew what he was doing. He went first, skiing down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew into the air, but something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and fell head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I liked practising turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it, and I was afraid of being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training centre in the US. It had a big indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students jumped and landed in foam cubes – not a real introduction to what we’d face on the slopes. After practising indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the centre’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat part behind the jump before the slope goes down again. Land in the right zone and you keep moving, which is less painful. Land on the flat and you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs would almost stop as I got close, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body does in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – I only remembered the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more problems before I finally landed right. Gareth was as happy as I was, and I felt proud. But that didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I kept my speed, jumped, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope, not on my feet anymore."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold tightly to the safety bar. The ride stops for a moment, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs up. There is a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You move quickly forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Everything is a blur, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose to be here, like millions of others who visit theme parks every year.

Amusement parks are a big business, with exciting rides that attract many people. To create these thrilling experiences, there are large teams of engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it is a real and challenging career. Designers must create rides that are both fun and safe, while also adding new features to keep visitors interested.

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most of the techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rides were more extreme, but now designers must work with the track designs from specialist manufacturers.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer', said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, an engineering expert, explained that it's about making people feel like they are being thrown around but still safe. The best rides tell a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and use new features like the tallest ride or the most twists to create a smooth experience.

Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trying different things are important. Jeff Hornick, a theme park development director, agreed that designers need to understand what passengers want and test the rides themselves. I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoasters. Walker said that while new technology is exciting, the physical rollercoaster experience will still be the most important part for many years.

Text: 'At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both activities with her busy schedule. ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it feels like to be in the studio taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day long,’ she says. As a choreographer, she teaches and enjoys working with young students. ‘A new dancer is often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they’re open to taking risks. They want success, but they don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses. This means they accept even harsh criticism. They might still challenge what I say sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’ When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There may be music I don’t like, but I still make sure I create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, that can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t choose a new piece of music. I’d like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces – it’d help lift the mood when rehearsals are tough. But now I’m always working on big productions – the music is already written and can’t be changed.’ Miranda doesn’t want to work with just one institution. ‘I think it’s important to meet new people. But I have to remember that all the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I have to be ready to change the way I work each time I go somewhere new, rather than do the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.’ We talk about a recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘There have been glamorous documentaries in the past which were misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one really tries to show viewers what life is like inside a dance company. There was one scene where a young dancer gets endless corrections and I smiled when I saw it. She knows she’s not getting it right but just can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s painful to watch but not made up for the cameras. The amount of work and dedication in ballet is underestimated by the public.’ I want to know what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything the company has invested in – the music, the costumes, the lighting, and the dancers – all come together. Perfection may be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and allows you to get away with a few wrong artistic choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance steps are great but something about the costumes or props distracts. And that’s disappointing.’ Miranda has done many different works, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? ‘People want to put a label on you and I don’t understand that. There’s a tendency to encourage expertise in a narrow area, too. I don’t agree with that, though the time may come when I’m happy to be known for doing one thing. For now, I just want to widen my horizons.’'

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that you can see amazing things on TV, but why stay at home on your sofa when there’s so much to experience outside? That conversation gave me the idea for my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend of mine was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and connected them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. I’ve been on several walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely new. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and it was on main roads. This meant I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while I sit on a rock. I got used to telling people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, I’m not training for a marathon”. When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I’d rather explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England than talk about the latest show on TV. You’ll be able to see the film on my website.'

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I decided a group holiday might be good for me. The man at the Greek port seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although still puzzled, he showed me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to chat before our first group swim. Our guides explained a support boat would go with us all the time, and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool, and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I’d hoped. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to complete this first distance, though, and was happy when I finally managed it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in; reaching a comfortable speed; stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, so did my speed and pleasure at completing them. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.'

Text: 'Being a flight attendant is not easy. But since I started the job, I have traveled everywhere, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, I have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. This makes it a great job for a young person like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school in another country, away from my family, so I always flew alone when school started and ended. Feeling lonely, I would ask the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers, and some of them let me. I remembered this later when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for something new. There were many young people at the interview, and many were accepted. They were often well-qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say – more than just saying I loved to travel, because everyone would say that. Instead, I talked about my strengths and past work experience – and I got the job! I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many things that make it worthwhile – but the free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying – ‘no-one’s finished till everyone’s finished.’ It’s like a big family – even though we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take work home. And if I do get difficult passengers, which doesn’t happen often, I know the flight will soon be over and I will probably never see them again!'

Text: 'At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Almost all the children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for most of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel great. We do have children who miss home at the beginning of the week. It's not the really young ones who feel like that the most – it's actually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can phone home after lunch. Then when they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it's a bit late to phone now, do it tomorrow. Most children are fine in a couple of days, and at the end of their week's stay, they all come up to us and thank us because they have had a great time. It's not always the children who feel lonely. We do get parents who are on the phone all the time, asking how their child is doing, which is not necessary. Often their son or daughter will be busy, playing games or doing something else, so we have to tell the parents to call back another time. We often get a certain type of child coming, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. Children like this usually argue when we tell them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand the reason why.'

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it was voted ‘Best Musical’ four times! Doing the show with only British actors was difficult. In the UK, there are more rules about how many shows young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Luckily, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they’ve just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it’s been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that were first popular in America. I met 11-year-old Jamie, one of the show’s actors. ‘It’s great that I get paid to play,’ he said, ‘especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me how busy the young actors are. ‘We have normal school lessons each day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ And what do they think of the show? ‘Well, my whole class came! The theatre has special deals on tickets for schools. They loved it and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played Days, a song I didn’t know. Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s ability and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! While the young actors were already musicians, with some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Fortunately, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show is in London for another year, and it is well worth seeing.'
